Posts.Content: Hi, Matt, This is just my 2 cents, and it means nothing, but at your age, radiation would be an issue for _me_. My doc, while a surgeon (which I get), answered me when I asked the question regarding radiation treatments with, "you're awfully young (51). I'd be concerned about the potential for side effects from the radiation, since you have a long time to live." While he's not a radiologist, he's a PCa researcher and well renowned at Johns Hopkins. When I first mentioned this to my uncle, who had PCa in the mid '90s (and is fine after perineural surgery-YIKES!), he said "I've known lots of guys that had seeds. They're all gone now." Now, I realize things have improved since then, but the main issue remains: What to do if it comes back? And the docs don't really know what's in you until it's in front of the microscope at pathology. I'm more wired for seeing an immediate PSA of ZERO, where some guys are OK with the potential fluctuations radiation normally brings. BTW, there are posts regarding the gel in this forum somewhere. I know it's a tough decision, but hey!! Now I've run out of excuses for putting that overdue colonoscopy off! Good luck, Ron P.S., I started off as a G6, too, and less than 5% in each of only 2 cores. Pathology said differently.

So, obviously there's a difference there. Where do you live, Fred?

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the 'other side' Steve. So, did you enjoy pressing that little green 'pain med' button every 10 minutes as much as I did? LOL! I only received one large bag also, which I was wearing of course, and a spare to take home, which I never used. I attended a seminar for upcoming PC surgery patients about 2 month prior to surgery and was told we would go home with a large bag only, so no surprises there. Honestly, it seemed more trouble than it was worth to change bags anyways. When I went for walks, I wore oversized sweatpants and simply wrapped the tube loosely around my leg a couple of times and let the bag lie at the bottom of the leg sleeve. The elastic at the leg bottom kept it from going anywhere. I was also told to use petroleum jelly. There was a reason about not using neosporin-type gels, but I don't remember why now. Were you sent home with a large 'goodie bag' of supplies like I was? There should be plenty of small packages of petroleum jelly in there as well as applicator sticks. I still had plenty of stuff leftover. The underwear they gave me with the replaceable pads was nice, but I found it easier to just use Depends for 'post-catheter' times as they are disposable, thus no washing. Hopkins was great. It's a great hospital.....but I wouldn't wander too far down the street in the dark, LOL! Good luck! Ron

Posts.Title: After Surgery Update

Posts.Content: Sorry you're here with us, TM. I was going to ask your age and testing history, but I see Shu already did that. You can add that stuff to your profile if you like so you don't get asked for it over and over again. Some tough numbers for sure. If your scans and tests are indicating that the cancer still hasn't escaped your prostate, you may still be a candidate for surgery. If it's gotten out, surgery probably isn't the best option. I have no knowledge of your doc. but if you are able to go the surgery route, you want a doc with lots of experience. I don't think you want to be someone's 'learning curve' with those Gleason 7s and 8s in there. By the same token, the same applies if you end up going the radiation route. You want experience. Williamsport is central-ish PA. right? Might be worth it to look into some of the major centers surrounding you. Philly, New York, Pittsburgh, maybe even Cleveland or Baltimore. Best wishes to you, sir!

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: Great post, Wishbone! Thanks for the hope! At exactly the 4 weeks mark today, I can feel a pretty good 'tingle' down there and some 'movement' when my wife and I share a real kiss, so I'm hopeful. I just wish the jealous dog would quit the incessant barking at us when we do, LOL! And here I was happy that, after 4 weeks to the day, I woke up with a dry pad for the first time. This even after having a lot of fluids yesterday as well as a couple Cap'n & Cokes! Where o' where have my dribbles gone?! Well, I'm not naive, but it was a nice way to start the day, just the same! I did get up 3 or 4 times to use the toilet, which was probably alcohol related, but I'll take that over a wet pad anyday! Hopefully, I'll be sharing a story similar to yours soon! Ron

Posts.Content: Hi again, Fredd. As Chuck has already alluded to, we really don't know what we've got until it's under the pathologist's microscope, which is a benefit of taking the surgical route--closer examination. Your '3+4' could end up being anything, even downgraded, but with your PSA where it is, I wouldn't count on that. If you'd like, you can create a 'history' and include it in your 'signature' line. You can also put your location in your profile. This way, as the posts become extended, we don't have to keep bugging you about it, lol! P.S., my wife is trying to convince us to take a visit next door to New Zealand this year or next. Is she nuts or what?! Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Signature: DOB: 8/1963--Great-Grandfather/Uncle had PC 9/13 PSA 4.85, 2/14 PSA 6.7, TRUS Bx 12 core-neg, 6/14 PSA 4.8, 12/14 PSA 5.9, PCA3: 38, 1/15 PSA 5.4 (switched docs to JH), 3/15 PSA 5.8/fPSA 17.4/PHI 28.4, 3/15 3T MRI/Fusion-Guided Bx @ Johns Hopkins, 2/14 cores pos, bilateral, <5% involvement, Gleason 6, Open RP: 8/10/2015 w/ Dr. Carter @ JH Final Pathology: LN-, SV-, Margins-, EPE- Tumor Extent: Moderate, organ confined Gleason upstaged to 3+4=7 (2% pattern 4) Additional Findings: HGPIN pT2cNO (Stage IIB) PSA 11/2015 <.1, 05/2016 <.1, 09/2016 .02 & 3/2017 .02 (both using different assays), 09/2017 <.1, 03/2018 <.1
Posts.Title: Dr Surprised but 'not alarmed' at PSA after surgery.

Posts.Content: Welcome Winter. Man, looking at your screen name almost makes me envious as I go through yet another day of baking in the East Coast heat and humidity! Tough luck on the divorce. Feel free to "bounce things off" of us, as I also believe having support is important. We're not doctors, but everyone here has dealt with this disease in one way or another and the experiences are vast and varied. You may get the impression that this forum seems to lean more towards surgery for treatment--especially in younger men. I can't personally comment on other options as I went (kicking and screaming, lol) the surgery route. I was only 51 at Dx and I'm sure I already had it at 50--or even in my late 40s--but it wasn't until that first screening PSA test just after my 50th birthday that started this thing rolling. My post-surgery path report upped my Gleason a bit, and that's one of the benefits to surgery--it's 'out' and be thoroughly examined under the 'scope for a complete examination. I just passed the 11 month post-op mark and I'm doing well. I'll still only be 53 next month, so doing well is still important to me, too! Chuck pretty much covered what you're looking at, but I just wanted to say "hell" and welcome aboard! I'd also be a little suspect with only one core of PCa found, but with your PSA numbers being where they are. Blind biopsies aren't perfect by any means, and they can certainly miss other tumors, so the 3T is sound advice if you can get it. Best of luck-- Ron P.S., adding your location to your profile would be helpful. Then we don't have to keep bugging you about it!

Posts.Title: New Here

Posts.Content: Jake, as a graduate of the Johns Hopkins school of cutlery myself. I don't think you'll have anything to worry about. No problem with stairs. I had to go up them to shower/shave. I slept in my recliner for the catheter period. I was discharged WITHOUT a smaller leg bag, but with 2 regular bags and an assortment of bandages and ointments. I don't really think the small bag would've been of much use, and I didn't need the 2nd large bag. You'll figure it out. Ron

Posts.Content: Am I making a wise choice to have the operation at this stage. Yes. but I've been told that that is not really much better than 4+3 I disagree, and hope you're wrong!!! Seriously though, if you have to have a G7 score, you'd want the 3+4 variety, which, under the newer scoring system is considered 'Grade 2' (on a 1-5 scale) whereas a 4+3 would be a 'Grade 3.' So, obviously there's a difference there. Where do you live, Fred?

Posts.Content: Good report Gary. Congrats. When you see your Uro, would you mind asking him about his thoughts regarding the newer staging from the AJCC 8th Edition? The 8th edition no longer delineates the different pathology results for stage 2. It states 'pathologically organ-confined disease is now considered pT2 and is no longer sub-classified by extent of involvement or laterality,' I see these sub-classifications still being used, and am wondering why.. Keep the faith! Ron

Posts.Content: Hi again, Fredd. As Chuck has already alluded to, we really don't know what we've got until it's under the pathologist's microscope, which is a benefit of taking the surgical route--closer examination. Your '3+4' could end up being anything, even downgraded, but with your PSA where it is, I wouldn't count on that. If you'd like, you can create a 'history' and include it in your 'signature' line. You can also put your location in your profile. This way, as the posts become extended, we don't have to keep bugging you about it, lol! P.S., my wife is trying to convince us to take a visit next door to New Zealand this year or next. Is she nuts or what?! Best of luck. Ron

I thought we were all about not making treatment judgement opinions on here. And if we were all in our 70s, our decisions may be different. Whatever...I'm having a bad day. Peace!

Posts.Title: Am I making the right choice for surgery now.

Posts.Content: Hi, Matt, This is just my 2 cents, and it means nothing, but at your age, radiation would be an issue for _me_. My doc, while a surgeon (which I get), answered me when I asked the question regarding radiation treatments with, "you're awfully young (51). I'd be concerned about the potential for side effects from the radiation, since you have a long time to live." While he's not a radiologist, he's a PCa researcher and well renowned at Johns Hopkins. When I first mentioned this to my uncle, who had PCa in the mid '90s (and is fine after perineural surgery-YIKES!), he said "I've known lots of guys that had seeds. They're all gone now." Now, I realize things have improved since then, but the main issue remains: What to do if it comes back? And the docs don't really know what's in you until it's in front of the microscope at pathology. I'm more wired for seeing an immediate PSA of ZERO, where some guys are OK with the potential fluctuations radiation normally brings. BTW, there are posts regarding the gel in this forum somewhere. I know it's a tough decision, but hey!! Now I've run out of excuses for putting that overdue colonoscopy off! Good luck, Ron P.S., I started off as a G6, too, and less than 5% in each of only 2 cores. Pathology said differently.

Posts.Title: Peter Grimm Study is compelling!

Posts.Content: Mike, just my humble thoughts. You're going to a top center. I wouldn't worry about the doc's 'social skills' as much as his skills with the knife. You won't be life-long friends. Michael F has very good points--as usual. I was a bit worried when I saw my doc for the first time at Johns Hopkins. I was concerned a bit because he didn't do 'robotic' and that was what we are all so used to hearing about now a days. But, he turned out to be a nice enough guy, seemed empathetic, and offered me lots of reassurances. I have no regrets in letting him filet me, lol! I also had some of Michael's similar 'wife thoughts' but mine went more like this after our post-biopsy meeting with Dr. Carter: Wife: "Well, that's a relief." Me: "What is?" Wife: "The decision we have to make." Me: "But I was hoping I'd have the option to at least watch it for a while." Wife: (odd look) "We're not doing that." Me: "But if..." Wife: "We're not doing that." Me: "If I can..." Wife: "We're NOT DOING THAT!" A couple of months later---- Wife: "Hi honey. Have you made the call to schedule your surgery yet?" Me: No, but I was just thinking about it. Wife: "Hmmph. You're a PAIN IN THE ASS! I'm coming home. We're going to sit down and call this in together and make this happen. I'm not losing you over this BS!" Me: " Umm...it's OK honey. I'll call right now." Tough love! But she' knows me too well by now! At least I can laugh about it now.

Posts.Content: Great post, Wishbone! Thanks for the hope! At exactly the 4 weeks mark today, I can feel a pretty good 'tingle' down there and some 'movement' when my wife and I share a real kiss, so I'm hopeful. I just wish the jealous dog would quit the incessant barking at us when we do, LOL! And here I was happy that, after 4 weeks to the day, I woke up with a dry pad for the first time. This even after having a lot of fluids yesterday as well as a couple Cap'n & Cokes! Where o' where have my dribbles gone?! Well, I'm not naive, but it was a nice way to start the day, just the same! I did get up 3 or 4 times to use the toilet, which was probably alcohol related, but I'll take that over a wet pad anyday! Hopefully, I'll be sharing a story similar to yours soon! Ron

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: Welcome to the 'other side' Steve. So, did you enjoy pressing that little green 'pain med' button every 10 minutes as much as I did? LOL! I only received one large bag also, which I was wearing of course, and a spare to take home, which I never used. I attended a seminar for upcoming PC surgery patients about 2 month prior to surgery and was told we would go home with a large bag only, so no surprises there. Honestly, it seemed more trouble than it was worth to change bags anyways. When I went for walks, I wore oversized sweatpants and simply wrapped the tube loosely around my leg a couple of times and let the bag lie at the bottom of the leg sleeve. The elastic at the leg bottom kept it from going anywhere. I was also told to use petroleum jelly. There was a reason about not using neosporin-type gels, but I don't remember why now. Were you sent home with a large 'goodie bag' of supplies like I was? There should be plenty of small packages of petroleum jelly in there as well as applicator sticks. I still had plenty of stuff leftover. The underwear they gave me with the replaceable pads was nice, but I found it easier to just use Depends for 'post-catheter' times as they are disposable, thus no washing. Hopkins was great. It's a great hospital.....but I wouldn't wander too far down the street in the dark, LOL! Good luck! Ron

Posts.Title: New Member, Many Questions,Central Pa.

Posts.Content: Welcome Winter. Man, looking at your screen name almost makes me envious as I go through yet another day of baking in the East Coast heat and humidity! Tough luck on the divorce. Feel free to "bounce things off" of us, as I also believe having support is important. We're not doctors, but everyone here has dealt with this disease in one way or another and the experiences are vast and varied. You may get the impression that this forum seems to lean more towards surgery for treatment--especially in younger men. I can't personally comment on other options as I went (kicking and screaming, lol) the surgery route. I was only 51 at Dx and I'm sure I already had it at 50--or even in my late 40s--but it wasn't until that first screening PSA test just after my 50th birthday that started this thing rolling. My post-surgery path report upped my Gleason a bit, and that's one of the benefits to surgery--it's 'out' and be thoroughly examined under the 'scope for a complete examination. I just passed the 11 month post-op mark and I'm doing well. I'll still only be 53 next month, so doing well is still important to me, too! Chuck pretty much covered what you're looking at, but I just wanted to say "hell" and welcome aboard! I'd also be a little suspect with only one core of PCa found, but with your PSA numbers being where they are. Blind biopsies aren't perfect by any means, and they can certainly miss other tumors, so the 3T is sound advice if you can get it. Best of luck-- Ron P.S., adding your location to your profile would be helpful. Then we don't have to keep bugging you about it!

Posts.Content: Good report Gary. Congrats. When you see your Uro, would you mind asking him about his thoughts regarding the newer staging from the AJCC 8th Edition? The 8th edition no longer delineates the different pathology results for stage 2. It states 'pathologically organ-confined disease is now considered pT2 and is no longer sub-classified by extent of involvement or laterality,' I see these sub-classifications still being used, and am wondering why.. Keep the faith! Ron

Posts.Content: Jake, as a graduate of the Johns Hopkins school of cutlery myself. I don't think you'll have anything to worry about. No problem with stairs. I had to go up them to shower/shave. I slept in my recliner for the catheter period. I was discharged WITHOUT a smaller leg bag, but with 2 regular bags and an assortment of bandages and ointments. I don't really think the small bag would've been of much use, and I didn't need the 2nd large bag. You'll figure it out. Ron

Posts.Title: Question about post-op/catheter and stairs

Posts.Content: Welcome, Caddy.... Just my 2 cents, and I'm no expert by any means. Your G6, combined with your CAT scan results, seems to put you at no big rush, although the 5 positive & bilateral cores is a little disconcerting. If you went 10 years, and though it was no longer 'curable' but treatable for another number of years, would that be OK with you? But more to my real point. If you're going to go the surgery route and base your decision on a robotic vs. traditional surgeon, I urge you to do some research before making that the deciding factor. A robot doesn't make a surgeon better--experience does. I had 'open' with an experienced doc, and I'm doing well thus far. Where are you located? Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Question about post-op/catheter and stairs

Posts.Content: Mike, just my humble thoughts. You're going to a top center. I wouldn't worry about the doc's 'social skills' as much as his skills with the knife. You won't be life-long friends. Michael F has very good points--as usual. I was a bit worried when I saw my doc for the first time at Johns Hopkins. I was concerned a bit because he didn't do 'robotic' and that was what we are all so used to hearing about now a days. But, he turned out to be a nice enough guy, seemed empathetic, and offered me lots of reassurances. I have no regrets in letting him filet me, lol! I also had some of Michael's similar 'wife thoughts' but mine went more like this after our post-biopsy meeting with Dr. Carter: Wife: "Well, that's a relief." Me: "What is?" Wife: "The decision we have to make." Me: "But I was hoping I'd have the option to at least watch it for a while." Wife: (odd look) "We're not doing that." Me: "But if..." Wife: "We're not doing that." Me: "If I can..." Wife: "We're NOT DOING THAT!" A couple of months later---- Wife: "Hi honey. Have you made the call to schedule your surgery yet?" Me: No, but I was just thinking about it. Wife: "Hmmph. You're a PAIN IN THE ASS! I'm coming home. We're going to sit down and call this in together and make this happen. I'm not losing you over this BS!" Me: " Umm...it's OK honey. I'll call right now." Tough love! But she' knows me too well by now! At least I can laugh about it now.

Posts.Title: WooHoo for the < sign!

Posts.Content: USPSTF-----Pure BUNK, IMO! It never even occurred to me to ask about a PSA test. I'd forgotten about some family history and felt more or less fine. It was my doc that told me he was ordering a PSA test along with my routine blood work as I had just turned 50. Literally, like 3 weeks earlier. In hindsight, I should've asked for the test earlier. Frankly, I feel quite lucky knowing that I dodged a potential bullet with my ignorance of the subject and mine hadn't already spread. Then you see guys here and elsewhere in their early-mid 40s that likely never had a PSA test in their lives because they weren't 'old enough' and it was only found after it had metastisized and they had symptoms. It isn't like a PSA test is some kind of exotic, expensive test. Yeah, it may cause some men to worry needlessly, but that, IMO, is a small price to pay for the discovery of what _should_ be a curable disease if detected early. Personally, I think 40 years old should be the routine testing start date. I've talked to a couple of guys that were in ther 40s that I knew were higher risk. I urged them to consider the test. Even if their insurance wouldn't cover it due to their age, it's cheap! And worth it for the peice of mind. I wish these 'experts' would let it rest. It isn't that big of a deal to get the test, and if it comes back elevated, other causes can be ruled out. I've seen to many here and elsewhere who are alive now because of this simple test. OK.....rant over. LOL! Ron

Posts.Content: Good luck, MB. The blood in the urine will get better. You may pass a small clot or two, but don't get too alarmed. Posts.Title: Surgeon in Northern VA?

Posts.Content: Hi Houndly. And unfortunately, welcome. I have to echo the other posters and say, if I was in NoVa, I'm going to Hopkins. I had to make a similar decision recently since, while I was happy with my doctor for the initial stuff, Hopkins is just over 30 minutes from me, and I thought it unwise to not take advantage of the facility (It didn't hurt that the initial doc missed my PCa at biopsy and recommended a saturation biopsy, afterwards). While you're probably about 1.5 hours away, most NoVa-ers spend that in traffic each way to work! If you don't want to do the round trip, maybe spend the night in a local hotel, pick up an O's game, and/or have some crabs at the Inner Harbor. My samples were reviewed by Dr. Epstein at Hopkins. Why risk a biopsy and have second thoughts about the results, and consider sending them off for a second opinion--which Hopkins charges for and Epstein is often the reviewer? Think about this: Men come from around the world to the Brady Urological Clinic for treatment, and you're only in NoVa. Besides, Hopkins has the latest equipment. The 3T MRI found the suspicious area that my initial biopsy didn't. While I had to have a second biopsy, it wasn't "saturation" and the doc knew where he was aiming. Remember, some of the choices you may be about to face in the future are potentially big ones. No point in fooling around! It would be helpful though, if you posted what your "stats" are. You can add them to your signature line. Good luck!

Think about this: Men come from around the world to the Brady Urological Clinic for treatment, and you're only in NoVa. Besides, Hopkins has the latest equipment. The 3T MRI found the suspicious area that my initial biopsy didn't. While I had to have a second biopsy, it wasn't "saturation" and the doc knew where he was aiming. Remember, some of the choices you may be about to face in the future are potentially big ones. No point in fooling around! It would be helpful though, if you posted what your "stats" are. You can add them to your signature line. Good luck!

Posts.Title: Another update

Posts.Content: Good news, Z! Your story reminded me of a bit of a concern that I have also. When I spoke to my surgeon a couple of weeks ago, he told me he didn't need to speak with me for more follow ups unless I had concerns--then give him a call. I do however have a PSA ordered at Hopkins for early next month, which will be my 2nd post-surgery. It's a bit of a hassle to go into downtown Baltimore, but I'm trying to stay consistent with the labs (JH has an express lab on premises). Doc said I was doing well at this point, so while he normally has phone appointments every 3 months for the first year, I can forgo the rest of those. I see that as good news, but I'd already asked my primary care doc if he's going to take over my PSA testing along with my regular blood work after my surgeon 'releases me' so to speak, and he said he will, but I'm concerned I'm going to run into the same issues many have with a lab switch. I guess the 'assay' that the lab uses is what's most important. Then again, I'm not sure if JH even used the same method for me. My post-op PSA shows the method as 'Ag-TOSOH' while my pre-op shows 'Hybritech'. Now this brings me to a question of my own, as I've heard conflicting info, but is the test method used slightly different for those that are 'pre-surgery' and those 'post-surgery?' I wondered if that could explain the difference with the assays used. Anyways, thanks guys for listening to me ramble! And again, Z. Great news!!! Ron

Posts.Content: Welcome fella. Yeah, most of us have been through the ringer with these various tests. Ask your doc if it makes sense to test you for Free PSA and/or PHI. My understanding is that they are both more beneficial for PSA readings in the 4-10 range (as are prostate density calculations). I don't believe the PCA3 test has such a PSA range preference. The PCA3 won't tell you if you have cancer either, but it is intended to indicate the probability of finding prostate cancer in a biopsy. Of those that I had, other than the PSA, the PCA3 seemed to be of some value with a score of 38, which showed an 'increased probability' of finding PC on biopsy, of course the irony is that I had already had a biopsy--which was negative! Go figure!!! My PHI and FPSA both indicated a less than 20% probability of PC, but that wasn't to be. PCA3 is urine based. Doc will perform a little more rigorous DRE than normal, and then you'll give a urine sample. No big deal. Good luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Looking back

Posts.Content: Welcome fella. Yeah, most of us have been through the ringer with these various tests. Ask your doc if it makes sense to test you for Free PSA and/or PHI. My understanding is that they are both more beneficial for PSA readings in the 4-10 range (as are prostate density calculations). I don't believe the PCA3 test has such a PSA range preference. The PCA3 won't tell you if you have cancer either, but it is intended to indicate the probability of finding prostate cancer in a biopsy. Of those that I had, other than the PSA, the PCA3 seemed to be of some value with a score of 38, which showed an 'increased probability' of finding PC on biopsy, of course the irony is that I had already had a biopsy--which was negative! Go figure!!! My PHI and FPSA both indicated a less than 20% probability of PC, but that wasn't to be. PCA3 is urine based. Doc will perform a little more rigorous DRE than normal, and then you'll give a urine sample. No big deal. Good luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Editorial: Bad Prostate Cancer Advice

Posts.Content: #1: I recently had my primary care doc take over with my PSA tests as Dr. Carter told me he didn't think I needed follow up at this time. nor did we have to have our 'phone conferences' anymore as he felt I was doing well--unless I have concerns. I've been leery of this moment due to concern over the 'same lab' issue, but the drive into Baltimore to have Hopkins do the blood draw was a royal PITA at times. I came back at <.02, so I'm obviously relieved. I didn't ask, but do you guys know what testing method would've been used to get this number? I think if it was an uPSA it would have 3 number places right, or am I wrong? I believe the lab used was Solstas, which I also believe Quest is acquiring. #2: A long lost 2nd cousin of mine contacted me a couple of months ago regarding her 68 year old husband's recently diagnosed PC. We've been talking, and he just went through RALP in August at Mercy Hospital in Baltimore (he worked there and was comfy with some of the docs, otherwise I was suggesting Johns Hopkins). He's recovered well, but apparently the path report found 'microscopic cells' at a margin. His PSA at 3 weeks post-op was .09, which is too early to really tell IMO (maybe the doc wanted a 'nadir' baseline) and he will get another PSA this upcoming week. The doc said he couldn't even see the margin cells under the magnification, and he was surprised by the report but still seemed confident of a good outcome. Path Gleason was 3+4=7. But, what I really wanted to ask was this: He had NO lymph nodes removed. Is this even normal anymore? I'm sure that's sitting in the backs of their minds, knowing PC was found at the margin, and no lymph nodes were dissected, has to be making them uncomfortable. Their doc said, based on the pre-surgery info, he didn't feel removal of lymph nodes was necessary, but I had 11 removed, and I didn't seem to be at risk of anything out of the capsule (after imaging) pre-surgery either. They hadn't even thought of anything beyond the surgery as they were relying on the confidence of their doc, and now he's mentioning potential radiation. I sure wish they would've gone to Hopkins, about 15 minutes away from this hospital..... Thanks guys. The lymph node thing has me thinking..... Ron

He's supposed to have another PSA draw this week, which would but him at about 6 weeks out post-op.

Posts.Content: Thanks, Chuck. Yeah, I believe I've read of guys on this board that didn't have lymph node dissection--though it seems to be rare. I was suspected of only G6 too when I went under the knife, and the doc still took 11 LNs. But as MM said, after discovering that PM, I would certainly feel more comfortable knowing my LNs were checked. But, hindsight is 20/20, right? I'm not sure if he was Dx'ed with G6 or G7 prior to surgery. I do know he didn't have a MRI or any imaging done prior to the surgery, only the TRUS biopsy. Again, I wish my hint that they go to Hopkins was heeded, but there's that 'hindsight' again, lol. I'll find out more later this week. I don't want to overload them with information as I think this path report has caused some stress already. Thanks, again Ron

Posts.Title: 2 questions guys.....

Posts.Content: #1: I recently had my primary care doc take over with my PSA tests as Dr. Carter told me he didn't think I needed follow up at this time. nor did we have to have our 'phone conferences' anymore as he felt I was doing well--unless I have concerns. I've been leery of this moment due to concern over the 'same lab' issue, but the drive into Baltimore to have Hopkins do the blood draw was a royal PITA at times. I came back at <.02, so I'm obviously relieved. I didn't ask, but do you guys know what testing method would've been used to get this number? I think if it was an uPSA it would have 3 number places right, or am I wrong? I believe the lab used was Solstas, which I also believe Quest is acquiring. #2: A long lost 2nd cousin of mine contacted me a couple of months ago regarding her 68 year old husband's recently diagnosed PC. We've been talking, and he just went through RALP in August at Mercy Hospital in Baltimore (he worked there and was comfy with some of the docs, otherwise I was suggesting Johns Hopkins). He's recovered well, but apparently the path report found 'microscopic cells' at a margin. His PSA at 3 weeks post-op was .09, which is too early to really tell IMO (maybe the doc wanted a 'nadir' baseline) and he will get another PSA this upcoming week. The doc said he couldn't even see the margin cells under the magnification, and he was surprised by the report but still seemed confident of a good outcome. Path Gleason was 3+4=7. But, what I really wanted to ask was this: He had NO lymph nodes removed. Is this even normal anymore? I'm sure that's sitting in the backs of their minds, knowing PC was found at the margin, and no lymph nodes were dissected, has to be making them uncomfortable. Their doc said, based on the pre-surgery info, he didn't feel removal of lymph nodes was necessary, but I had 11 removed, and I didn't seem to be at risk of anything out of the capsule (after imaging) pre-surgery either. They hadn't even thought of anything beyond the surgery as they were relying on the confidence of their doc, and now he's mentioning potential radiation. I sure wish they would've gone to Hopkins, about 15 minutes away from this hospital..... Thanks guys. The lymph node thing has me thinking..... Ron

There are certainly cases where he's downgraded the Gleason score, which may play into your options. After my second biopsy, this one at JH, while he didn't evaluate the original biopsy sample himself (a resident pathologist did that), he approved the results. It gave me some comfort. Ron One benefit to living in Maryland, I guess...lol!

Posts.Title: new to Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Welcome, Badda.....If you'd like 'help to decide on a treatment' you probably shouldn't rule out surgery posting here as many of us have chosen that option as our preferred treatment. I think we can all relate to the apprehension, but it's not the end of the world. Do you have specific concerns regarding surgery over your 'already chosen' other options? As Chuck has asked already, can you tell us your age--and location as well? Your PSA doesn't seem to indicate aggressive cancer, and at a G6, you've got time to decide. One thing regarding surgery: Once it's out it can be assessed by pathology. Often times the Gleasons are upstaged after pathology, as a biopsy can only stage what the needle hits. Often---there's more, and more serious cancer lurking in there. Not saying this is your situation, and hopefully it isn't, but you should understand that it happens. Interesting, current read:http://www.cancernetwork.com/news/ra...=1&ts=23122015 Best of luck to you.

Posts.Title: Need help with my two options, VMAT or Proton

Posts.Content: Thanks Doctor K. I, for one, appreciate having a medical professional chime in from time to time, as we're all laymen here. We certainly try to help those facing this disease through our own experience, but we can't give the 'physician's side' of the treatment. So, thank you for that. Obviously, I'm far past those 'newer treatment' options and personally, I don't think I was wired for keeping that thing in me! But, it's nice to see more options become available for the next generation. I would certainly agree that yearly screening via imaging would be beneficial to men. My wife recently had her 2nd mammogram @ 50 years old and something 'suspicious' was found, which resulted in a second mammogram which, thankfully, was deemed to be negative. She knows she's going to be pretty much getting her boobs squished on a yearly basis, especially considering her mother passed last year from breast cancer related disease (her aggressive treatment apparently resulted in fast onset leukemia). Why shouldn't this imaging be the norm for men, too.? Maybe at 50 years old, or 40 if there's a family history of the disease? I know women have complained about their feeling shorted on the screening and preventive side of medicine in years past, so maybe it's about time more men get involved, too?! Again, thanks for your input from time to time. Ron

Posts.Title: Need help with my two options, VMAT or Proton

Posts.Content: It's great that your hospital got the new 3T just in time for you, but man.....that's a lot of needles! It gives me the heebie-jeebies just thinking about it! LOL!!! I had the same "fusion" procedure, but with the standard 12-core TRUS, plus 2 additional cores where the "suspicious" area was identified. Also, don't be surprised if the bloody urine returns. After 2 biopsies, both took about a week before it was completely gone. I'd think it was over with, but then I'd get a "dribble" or two. I told my wife I was going to pee in the dark so I didn't have to look at it. Needless to say, that went over well!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Completed today

Posts.Content: Hi, Spostre. As you can see in my signature, I've had a couple of biopsies as well as a 3T, so the second was fusion-guided and much more accurate. I understand your other health concerns, but the only way you, and your docs, will know what the suspicious area is, is if the Bx is performed. Thankfully, you seem to have a good Uro in that he suggested the 3T prior to a biopsy. While this will hopefully become the 'standard' all too often a 'blind' biopsy is done and, since the docs are 'shooting blind' the cancer is frequently missed (as was my case). Hopefully you are wrong about your life expectancy as you're only 47. While your PSA numbers aren't really suggestive of cancer in themselves (though it happens)--particularly an aggressive cancer, a lot of bad things can happen if untreated within 10 years. The Bx isn't too bad. Ask your doc for numbing gel prior to the numbing needle. That made a much more comfortable Bx #2. If something is found you may even be able to participate in an active surveillance program. Also, do you have a family history of PCa? Father, grandfather, great-grandfather, maybe? BTW, can you advice us what area you live in? Good luck, Ron And PDV: I didn't get the bennie of a 'hot nurse' during either of mine--it was a dude, but when I had a vasectomy a couple of years ago, I had 2 of them in there with me & the doc. Talk about pressure!

Posts.Title: Biopsy upcoming. Hope I'm doing the right thing.

Posts.Content: Gulfcoaster.....first of all, welcome. I can't really comment regarding your initial question regarding treatment. I guess I never paid attention to that. A lot of times treatment is based on age, as well as the PCa being confined to the capsule. Other times it comes down to the 'what ifs' if secondary treatment may be needed down the road, and other times, it comes down with guys that just aren't comfortable knowing they have something cancerous growing inside them, and they just want it OUT! Now I'll ask: What was your Gleason Score of the 2 positive samples after your first biopsy? Were they both found on the same side of your prostate, or on both sides (bilateral)? As far as the second biopsy goes, blind biopsies are far from perfect and yours wouldn't be the first time cancer that was missed during the procedure (my first one was negative). And it's also a possibility that more serious cancer was missed during both biopsies. Have you had any imaging done, other than the ultrasound during the biopsy? Your PSA of 10 isn't anywhere near normal and you already know you have cancer from your first bx. Many of the guys on this forums had quite low PSA numbers, but when cancer was found, it was very aggressive. Mine was in the mid-5s when I was dxed. This is from your only other post: Several years ago my PSA started to raise above 4. My urologist suggested I have a biopsy performed and found 2 of the 12 cores with 10-20% cancer. Over the last 3 years My PSA has raisin from 4 to 6 to 10. The cancer was slow moving ( thank goodness ). The second year followed about what the first year results showed. Now the mystery begins. This week I received a call from my urologist and he informed me the current results did not show any cancer. This should be great news but in the back of my mind someone must have screwed up. My PSA is at 10. Any idea as to what's going on? I am scheduled for another PSA in 4 months. Your PSA isn't going in any direction but 'up.' That isn't normal, and you've already had a positive finding. We're not doctors here, but most have 'been through the ringer' so to speak, in one way or another. I would seriously ask about some imaging and then a follow-up biopsy. Do you know if a 3T Multiparametric MRI is available near you? The doc can then use those images if a suspicious area is found and perform a more accurate biopsy. If not that route, I'd consider asking for a 'saturation biopsy' via the perineum which uses many more needles (and you tend to be knocked out for that one--thank God, right?!). BTW, it would be helpful to know where you are located. You can include that with your profile. You can also include a brief history about your situation, as well as your age or DOB, in the 'signature' section of your profile page. Then we don't have to keep bugging you about it! Good luck. With a PSA of 10 and 2 positive cores (that you know of), I don't think I'd want to do a lot of 'waiting around.' Best wishes, Ron

The Bx isn't too bad. Ask your doc for numbing gel prior to the numbing needle. That made a much more comfortable Bx #2. If something is found you may even be able to participate in an active surveillance program. Also, do you have a family history of PCa? Father, grandfather, great-grandfather, maybe? BTW, can you advice us what area you live in? Good luck, Ron And PDV: I didn't get the bennie of a 'hot nurse' during either of mine--it was a dude, but when I had a vasectomy a couple of years ago, I had 2 of them in there with me & the doc. Talk about pressure!

Posts.Title: Biopsy Completed today

Posts.Content: Welcome VW. Sorry you find yourself here. I'm a little thrown off by your 'stats.' Your 'Left base PZ - 4+3 Gleason 7' seems to contradict your 'Primary Gleason at Biopsy = Pattern 3 Secondary Gleason at Biopsy = Pattern 4' that you noted. Maybe I'm missing something? Should you decide on the surgery route, I wouldn't fret over the 'open' vs. 'robotic' thing. A robot doesn't make a surgeon better. Experience does--and hopefully the doc you're seeing has plenty! I see the comment frequently made that the recovery is shorter with robotic, but I've yet to figure that out, since I went through 'open' myself. I was under the knife for about an hour and anesthesia not much longer. I was in the hospital the same amount of time with my surgery--one night in and out the following day. I barely had any fluid in my JP drain, I had virtually no pain, I had none of the gas pains that are frequently a complaint of the robot crowd here, and no constipation. I think I took a Percocet or two at the hospital because they insisted, and one or two more at home because I was worried about what may come, but I really only needed an occasional ibuprofen. From what I gathered, the way the incision is made doesn't cut much muscle, thus less pain. I did have a reaction to the metal abdominal stables. Not pain really, but itchy! That's not common though. I find it interesting that a normal stay for you would be 3 days, extended to 4 for the 'open' method. Is that a Canadian thing, maybe? In the USA, one night is standard, and out the door you go by the following evening! At 68, you should do well no matter the method---well, other than doing "nothing." That's likely not going to be recommended here! That 4+3, along with 9/12 cores positive, is calling you for treatment. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Just Received My Treatment Options

Posts.Content: Hi again, Cathy. If you haven't already, scan the 'sticky' threads at the top of this forum page and look particularly at the 'expectations' after DaVinci thread, as well as the others. As far as recovery, unfortunately everyone's experience is different. As far as working goes, keep in mind that he won't be able to lift anything heavier than a milk gallon for a few weeks. He'll have the catheter for about 10 days, so that will come into play also. So, it depends on his line of work, obviously, but I'd expect at least a couple of weeks--or more--off work. He can probably get by with wearing pads until his continence returns--which again, depends on the individual. I think for most, it's more of 'stress dribbles' when lifting, sitting, sneezing, coughing, laughing. etc. He'll want to stay up on his kegels to help. He's basically converting to having to pee like you gals do, lol! No more prostate to help him control his flow, so he has to learn to do it like the ladies do. As you will hear frequently, an experienced surgeon is an important key to good results, from continence to ED. Good luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Due to have Radical Prostatectomy in 2 weeks

Posts.Content: Welcome to the 'other side' Drbbt. You appear to be having a fine recovery. You're way early to be overly concerned about 'Rip' but it's understandable. My doc was clear to keep him stimulated, either with help or solo, so as to keep things flowing. It takes time and patience, but unfortunately, patience can be a tough monster to fight sometimes! Your pathology upgrade seems to be a common one, and pretty much what happened with me, including the 'bilateral' aspect, though I knew before surgery that a positive core was found on both lobes (even if I didn't quite understand what that meant at the time, other than AS wasn't an option). If I recall correctly, you're on the younger side, so you should eventually recover well, especially assuming your nerves were spared. Hopefully the rest of your path report was all good news, too. Hang in there, Ron

Posts.Content: Hi marysm, and welcome. 48 is on the young side to have PCa (not saying he does) but with his father having had the disease, that gives him a 1st degree relative who had it which increases his chances. I'm assuming this risk was known already since your hubby was having his PSA tested at <50 years old, which is the normal beginning testing age unless there's a family history--which there is in his case. Did he begin getting tested at 45, or were these his first tests? But yes, a PSA level of 6.9 is high, particularly for his age. However, there are other things that can affect PSA levels besides cancer. Did his doc prescribe any antibiotic to rule out any prostatitis? Any prostate enlargement noticed on the ultrasound? I would encourage you to read around this forum. Lots of useful info is sure to be found and feel free to ask away. Can you provide us your location? It may be helpful as you begin to have more questions. You can go into 'settings' and edit your profile and your location will display with your user name if you'd like.

Posts.Content: My doc advised me that I'd likely have to pay for some myself as insurance will only cover 6 pills per month. He didn't make a distinction between medically /recreationally necessary to me. At least there shouldn't be a restriction on the dosage, so ask for the highest available (Viagra is up to 100mg) and cut it up if possible (my primary care doc said that it's safe to do so with Viagra) to make it last as long as you can. Many folks only need 25 0r 50 mgs, so it helps to stretch it out a bit--pun intended!

Posts.Content: Hi Coupe. Sounds like you're frustrated. I was, too, after my first biopsy was negative (missed my cancer) yet my PSA levels were still too high/rising. You noted in a post a bit back regarding Vanderbilt now able to perform a MRI targeted biopsy. Did you have that done? There has to be something causing your PSA to elevate. However, depending on your age, maybe you can just do nothing. ***I also see that you post in the 'Hodgkin's and Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma Forum' so imagine you have a lot of stressors in your life.*** Sorry, bro. For the vast majority here, though, the PSA is what got the ball rolling. My first Uro told me up front that it is by no means perfect and I could get 2 different readings even with back-to-back PSAs. Have you asked about a 'PCA3' and/or 'PHI' test? Do you know your 'free psa' number? Best of luck to you, Ron

BTW, my grandfather's family is originally from M'town, but that was a while ago!

Posts.Title: Fifteen hours to go....

Posts.Content: Hi Coupe. Sounds like you're frustrated. I was, too, after my first biopsy was negative (missed my cancer) yet my PSA levels were still too high/rising. You noted in a post a bit back regarding Vanderbilt now able to perform a MRI targeted biopsy. Did you have that done? There has to be something causing your PSA to elevate. However, depending on your age, maybe you can just do nothing. ***I also see that you post in the 'Hodgkin's and Non-Hodgkin's Lymphoma Forum' so imagine you have a lot of stressors in your life.*** Sorry, bro. For the vast majority here, though, the PSA is what got the ball rolling. My first Uro told me up front that it is by no means perfect and I could get 2 different readings even with back-to-back PSAs. Have you asked about a 'PCA3' and/or 'PHI' test? Do you know your 'free psa' number? Best of luck to you, Ron

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Radiation

Posts.Content: Hi marysm, and welcome. 48 is on the young side to have PCa (not saying he does) but with his father having had the disease, that gives him a 1st degree relative who had it which increases his chances. I'm assuming this risk was known already since your hubby was having his PSA tested at <50 years old, which is the normal beginning testing age unless there's a family history--which there is in his case. Did he begin getting tested at 45, or were these his first tests? But yes, a PSA level of 6.9 is high, particularly for his age. However, there are other things that can affect PSA levels besides cancer. Did his doc prescribe any antibiotic to rule out any prostatitis? Any prostate enlargement noticed on the ultrasound? I would encourage you to read around this forum. Lots of useful info is sure to be found and feel free to ask away. Can you provide us your location? It may be helpful as you begin to have more questions. You can go into 'settings' and edit your profile and your location will display with your user name if you'd like.

Posts.Content: Yeah Jim, I certainly know it could be worse. That's probably why I don't read the other threads. And I'm just joking with Dave. It's how I deal with stress, I think! I'm certainly glad it was picked up before the situation got worse. As I've mentioned before, my stepfather's wasn't caught until it had escaped his prostate and was a Gleason 8 and he fought that battle for 6 years until he passed in April. No family history on his part, but Agent Orange exposure in Vietnam likely wasn't helpful. I'm certainly grateful I'm not in that situation. And while I'm a bit nervous about the surgery, I also look forward to getting it behind me. Damn you catheter bag!!!

Posts.Content: If it were me, I'd probably just wait until I get the results as maybe they'll be OK anyways. But if not OK, I'd request a re-test. When are your results due? That said, if it would put you more at ease, call the doc's office and ask if you can come in for a re-test due to your concerns over the DRE being performed first. My assumption is that your blood work from today is already at the lab, or enroute.

Posts.Title: My Urology Appointment

Posts.Content: I liked Aruba, but my wife won the trip due to business. Great people, but I didn't like the (IMO) lack of sightseeing (which I like to do) and we were seriously turned off by the timeshare sellers in downtown Oranjestad. This was 2000, so maybe that's better now. Great place for water play and drinking, though! My wife had won a Hawaii trip the year before ('99)--which was AWESOME! And the year after a trip to The Atlantis in Paradise Islands, Bahamas ('01). THAT was also awesome! We went back to The Atlantis for my 50th birthday in '13.

Posts.Title: Need a break

Posts.Content: My understanding is that in younger patients (I'm 51, btw), the aggressive approach is the way to go--get it out. My surgery is scheduled for August, and is via "open" but my surgeon at Johns Hopkins has had over 3500 guinea pigs before me--LOL! I've read some things that seem to infer "open" (as my doc does) via the retropubic approach, rather than the perirenal, has a better outcome for ED/incontinence in younger men as access to the nerves is better. But, as in all surgeries, experience matters. And I'm in Maryland, but I use "y'all" too! Just a FY!, but who I'm using:http://urology.jhu.edu/ballentinecarter/

Posts.Title: Need a break

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard Thom. In my very humble opinion, your PSA is kind of on the high side for a 3+3=6 Gleason, and it seems to be going in only one direction (not the good one) and approaching double digits, plus you already know you have cancer. I can't help but wonder if that initial biopsy missed something more serious in there (it happens, of course). Was your MRI of the 3T MP variety? Maybe ask your doc about a saturation biopsy in May? Good luck, Ron

Posts.Title: Big PSA jump. What does it mean?

Posts.Content: Seems like only yesterday that I was being wheeled down to the OR when, as the hallway became chilly and we approached some elevators I told the young man to stop so I could make a run for it. His response: "No way, man. I'm not going back and telling her that I lost you!" It seems my wife has powers! All in all doing well. I still do a shield most days for my own security, though I probably don't need it as much as I think I do and I've gone stints without one just fine. An occasional tiny squirt when I do something strenuous and I forget to plan for it. The ED thing is weird. I think I'm OK for the most part, but it seems to be less of an issue in the morning than at night. And forget about it if I've had a few drinks! What? No drinks?! Best wishes always to my fellow travelers!

Posts.Content: Welcome aboard Thom. In my very humble opinion, your PSA is kind of on the high side for a 3+3=6 Gleason, and it seems to be going in only one direction (not the good one) and approaching double digits, plus you already know you have cancer. I can't help but wonder if that initial biopsy missed something more serious in there (it happens, of course). Was your MRI of the 3T MP variety? Maybe ask your doc about a saturation biopsy in May? Good luck, Ron

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. Chuck and mikeg: Non-robotic. Retropubic--Open via the lower abdomen. As far as prep, no "colon cleanser" drinks. Just the Fleets enema in the morning. Maybe because mine is not via Mr. Robot? Dr. Carter told me at our last meeting that I'll have the cath in 9 days post surgery and then, if I want, I can remove it myself. IDK about that! Or they'll do it for me.....Hope so! We'll see. I may be so sick of it by then that I'll give it 'The ol' college try!" I spoke to a friend that had one after a TURP and did it himself. It didn't hurt, it just felt like he was pulling a snake outta there, lol! I hope they put that thing in me after I'm out. I don't wanna know what they're doing to me! Anyways, my final meet prior to this adventure beginning is tomorrow with the anesthesia department for their pre-op check, and I guess any final thoughts/instructions. All this drama, and I can't even find a decent pair of going home pants! What's a guy to do?! dshinnick/Dave: You make it out to Asheville yet? My wife and I bring that area up every now and then when we talk retirement.

Posts.Content: Bernard, do yourself a favor. If your friend offers you medical advice--don't take it! Even with the new technologies for imaging that are available now to detect PC, which can detect lesions, etc., they still all lead to a biopsy which is the only way to definitively detect (or rule out) PC. 'Thermography' is another imaging tool, right? All of these can only show suspicious areas, not confirm PC. "There has never ever...NEVER EVER... been anyone cured of cancer via radiation, surgery, chemo, or the big pharma medicines. They do not want a cure...they want an endless stream of $$$$. Most people have no idea what having "cancer in remission" means. It just means that the cancer has not grown in two months in succession based on PSA protein reading. You can be on deaths door step and have cancer in remission." So, what would your friend suggest, even if 'Thermography' was accurate and located something suspicious? Ignore the problem to punish the drug companies, or go with the current proven treatments that you described?

Posts.Content: Kozmic, I once saw a video with either Dr. Allaf or Dr Schaeffer at Johns Hopkins where he was explaining the robotic procedure and commented that robotic (RALP) was probably a better fit if the patient tended to be overweight than traditional open surgery (RRP). I had lost weight (I had RRP) but was still at about 245 (5'11") when I had mine. But I'd certainly defer to your doc and do as well as you can.

Posts.Title: Thought I had a plan

Posts.Content: You're good, man. By the 13th you'll just want to go home. By the 14th, you'll just want that catheter out! Sorry about your family though. Sunday (9/11) is the anniversary of my wife losing her mom to breast cancer treatment after effects. I have 2 great aunts that may not make it through the year (one is a definite--lung to brain cancer--and doesn't have much time left), and my grandmother will be 92 in December. I'm not so sure this will be a good year---for the 2nd in a row. Suggestion, but you should be physically OK by the time of your LV meet, but if nothing else, just wear Depends guards for the time there. They work, and it's not like anyone will know. Well, my wife told me my 'package' looked bigger while I was was wearing them, lol. And you will be in Vegas..... What happens in Vegas.....

Posts.Title: Big day is Monday

Posts.Content: I haven't posted in a bit, though I lurk (sorry, but my wife had spinal surgery in December and that has been a treat!). This question may have already been asked, but does anyone know off hand how long before life insurance is more likely to be available after RP? I bought a 'no questions asked' policy when I was retiring from law enforcement as a stopgap until I could get a normal policy (before diagnosis). Leaving my wife part of my retirement pension didn't make sense financially, so we figured out after I retired, I could cancel it and get a standard policy. Well, then this crap all happened..... I've been all undetectable since then (8/2015), and this August will be 3 years hopefully (THANK YOU DR. CARTER!!!). I know I won't get the best rates, but I'm hoping for better than the nearly $200 a month I'm paying now! I'll be 55 in August. Thanks, Ron

Posts.Title: Mr. Softee still in Zero Club

Posts.Content: Sorry. I obviously meant AJCC. Not sure my thread title edit is working. My apologies if this has been posted already. Effective January, 2018 the new 8th Edition staging manual takes effect. There are a few changes from the 7th edition. It looks like us pathologic pT2 guys are losing our alphabets! From what I've read elsewhere, there was controversy over the sub-categories under pT2, as hardly anyone had pT2b anyways, and by the time the tumor grew to the size to qualify for it, it almost always had invaded the other lobe, making it a T2c. Supposedly the subcategories didn't really seem to substantially alter outcomes either. Recent studies have failed to demonstrate the prognostic value of this distinction, so without evidence of clinical relevance for a subcategorized system, the eighth edition just uses a single pT2 category, for all organ-confined disease. The major changes are: T stage based on DRE only. Imaging is never used. (Nor is biopsy) Dropped the term extracapsular in favor of extraprostatic. No pathological T2 subcategories. The new 1-5 grouping system is being taken into consideration also. I don't want to risk violating a copyright in those pages' small print by posting a link or copying from the articles, but I'm sure Dr. Google will be of great assistance if anyone would like to read up on it. Ron

Posts.Title: Ultrasound guided prostate biopsy (looking for what to expect)

Posts.Content: Welcome Throwaway. Try not to get yourself too worked up at this point. Urination issues could very well just be an enlarged prostate, among other things. Has he had prior PSA tests, and could you give us a history of those if he has? If this was a sudden upswing, it's probably from something other than cancer. Cancer normally takes awhile to progress and produce those high numbers. By "goes in this week to find out if it's cancer" what do you mean exactly? Is he just going to see a urologist or has he seen one and is getting a biopsy? Any family history of PC for your dad's family? He'll probably be fine, but we get the concerns. If you'd provide your location in your profile, as well as your dad's history in your signature, that would be helpful. Best wishes. Ron

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Oh well, he is the top American authority on active surveillance, and that makes him a great fit for me. Yeah, I'd read about his AS program prior to seeing him. With only low volume of G6 in only two cores, I thought I was a shoe-in to consider it, although I knew I was a bit on the younger side. I was pretty surprised when he never even mentioned it during our post-Bx meeting---while my wife was relieved! She wanted nothing to do with AS. It was shortly thereafter I realized what having my tumor(s) 'bilateral' meant regarding the AS program. I'm not sure I was wired for it anyways, but if I could've bought a bit more times without the side effects, it would've been nice! But my overall experience with Dr. Carter, as well as the hospital, were definitely positive--all things considered.

Posts.Title: get a rating of surgeons in your area

Posts.Content: Hi Max and welcome. Just food for thought, as I'm one of the few it seems to have also had 'open' surgery, but there was little pain. I can't speak as to a 'pump' as the only pump I had was in my hospital room post-op when I could self administer my pain meds via a drip in my IV. Little green button every 10 minutes....might have been a placebo for all I know! I was prescribed some hydrocodone meds, but I only took them the first day or two home--out of precaution, and I doubt that I needed them. My doc had told me that most patients only need an Advil or two. My understanding is that since the incision runs 'North to South' that there is little muscle damage, which may cause more pain. I think my biggest aggravation, other than my catheter tube being determined to find cabinet knobs, was my sweat pants rubbing on the incision site. Were you not offered simply an option for regular pain pills? Good luck, Ron

Posts.Title: just found out

Posts.Content: Hi, func.... Your doc seems to be on par for the course. Have you had imaging that indicates your tumor is pushing out? With a G8, I wouldn't mess around. While radiation techniques are always improving, you kinda have to go with your gut, and it seems you've decided on surgery. Go for it and don't look back, IMO! IDK about the being 80 remark, but I'd personally feel better about it as a primary treatment if I were at least older than 57! I had 'open' surgery, and spent 1 night in the hospital (though I wouldn't have minded a second....it was quiet and relaxing, lol!) and cath time seems to run from 7-10 days as a norm. BTW, where are you located, and does your doc have a lot of experience with robotic surgery?

Posts.Title: Incontinence returns

Posts.Content: Pervert.....LOL! Good for you!!!!! I believe the skill of the surgeon is important--obviously--no matter what the method used is. My stepfather had robotic surgery and never got his full continence back until the day he passed from this disease--nearly 6 years later. My mom sort of wishes she would've insisted on his doing the 'open' surgery for him for more 'feedback' when dealing with the nerves down there. I have no idea how experienced his surgeon was, so I can't say, in his case, if it would've mattered. My doc does the traditional 'open' procedure, but with nearly 4000 of them under his belt, and as director of adult urology at Hopkins, I figured he knew what he was cuttin' at this point! 16 days post surgery, and I can 'make it work' and my continence is very good. The 'no fluid' orgasm thing is a bit weird though. Supposedly RRP has a bit longer total recovery time than RALP, but the time under anesthesia is shorter for 'open.' There's trade-offs for most things, I guess. 16 days later, and I feel fine. My only real annoyance is the incision site. As it runs about 4 inches vertically under my navel, it's kind of hard to not rub against it--unless being in the buff is your thing!!! But that will go away in time. My wife & I believe we made the right call changing docs, from a local Uro practice, to Johns Hopkins. I didn't want to hurt anyone's feelings either, but after a negative initial biopsy, a still high PSA, and the suggestion of a saturation biopsy under general anesthesia, I decided it was time for a different perspective. So, yes. Skill and experience are important. No matter how one wishes to proceed. BTW, my sister-in-law and her family lives just outside Boston, in Arlington. Sounds like you're doing well. Good news!!!

Posts.Content: Should I ask for an MRI first? In my opinion? Absolutely. 3T preferably. My first biopsy didn't find anything, as those things are really shooting blind and hoping to hit something. Well, often these tumors are quite small. Once I had my 3T MRI prior to my second biopsy, the doctor had a 'suspicious area' to target with the needles and this proved successful in my diagnoses.

Posts.Title: PSA increasing

Posts.Content: Hi Cubby. Just shouting out a big welcome to you as you've unfortunately found your way here! I'm running out the door to pick up my Viagra prescription (LOL!) but I'll mention that as far as checking your margins goes, and I assume you mean while you're still on the table having the surgeon running the prostate specimen over to pathology to examine the gland, I believe that to be surgeon-dependent. I don't think it's as common now (don't hold me to that!), maybe because surgical methods have gotten much more refined over the years. My doc did not do this, but I believe I've read on this forum of others that had this done. Have you had any imaging, like a MRI (3T) performed? As far as choosing goes, you'll probably get many responses to that. I was younger, at 51 when Dx'd and felt that I wanted it out and I didn't want to risk issues down the road with possible radiation side-effects (though these issues seem to be less of a problem as methods improve). While mine was 'only' a Gleason 6, it was on both sides/lobes and that made me a little uncomfortable. I also knew that until the gland was examined in pathology, I didn't really know what may be lurking in there. Turns out it was 3+4=7. There are more treatment options coming to bear now and they seem promising. I'll let others more knowledgeable than myself comment on them. I'm coming up on 9 months post-op and doing well, all things considered. If you'd like, you can post your 'history' over the years in your signature section, as well as your location in your profile. Then we don't have to keep pestering you with those questions. Best wishes, Ron

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Hi Cubby. Just shouting out a big welcome to you as you've unfortunately found your way here! I'm running out the door to pick up my Viagra prescription (LOL!) but I'll mention that as far as checking your margins goes, and I assume you mean while you're still on the table having the surgeon running the prostate specimen over to pathology to examine the gland, I believe that to be surgeon-dependent. I don't think it's as common now (don't hold me to that!), maybe because surgical methods have gotten much more refined over the years. My doc did not do this, but I believe I've read on this forum of others that had this done. Have you had any imaging, like a MRI (3T) performed? As far as choosing goes, you'll probably get many responses to that. I was younger, at 51 when Dx'd and felt that I wanted it out and I didn't want to risk issues down the road with possible radiation side-effects (though these issues seem to be less of a problem as methods improve). While mine was 'only' a Gleason 6, it was on both sides/lobes and that made me a little uncomfortable. I also knew that until the gland was examined in pathology, I didn't really know what may be lurking in there. Turns out it was 3+4=7. There are more treatment options coming to bear now and they seem promising. I'll let others more knowledgeable than myself comment on them. I'm coming up on 9 months post-op and doing well, all things considered. If you'd like, you can post your 'history' over the years in your signature section, as well as your location in your profile. Then we don't have to keep pestering you with those questions. Best wishes, Ron

Posts.Title: RP the day before yesterday

Posts.Content: Hi, Tim.... I had 'open' rather than 'robotic' but here ya go: 1. It seems as if a lot of men suffer from Bladder Spasm's due to having their catheter in. And some describe them as a constant urge to urinate and others describe it as an excruciating pain. I am curious how often this happens and how much of a problem this was for you? Be honest here. Also, if this did happen to you, did you find anything that brought them on and anything that minimized or eliminated them ? Thankfully, I never had this occur. Or if I did, I didn't know it. Either way, I'm good with that! 2. What will my diet be like following surgery and how long will it take to improve? I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? The day of surgery, I was on a liquid diet that evening post-op. Broth and Jello, I believe. The next day I was allowed oatmeal. Once I got home, it was recommended to take it lightly for a couple of days, but no real dietary restrictions. Scrambled eggs were fine. 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight. My surgery was around 7:15 a.m., but I had to be there to check in at 5:15 a.m. Ugh! And I had to do a Fleets enema before leaving the house. Nothing says "good times" like lying on the bathroom floor at 3:30 a.m. sticking a watery tube up your a......, well, you know! I was released to go home at around 4:30 p.m. the day after surgery. The CNP, who we met before the surgery, pulled my drain tube about an hour or so before discharge. 4. It seems the general advice is to sleep on a recliner rather than a bed following Robotic Prostatectomy. I am curious why this is and what is the actual thing that makes sleeping in a bed difficult ? Reason I ask is because I don't have a recliner. For those of you who didn't have a recliner, how did you manage sleeping ? Also, how long does it take (Days?) until you were able to sleep on a regular bed ? I also recommend a recliner, though other guys make a bed work. For one thing, you don't have to worry so much about rolling over on your cath tube. You also want to keep the cath bag below your bladder level to decrease the chances of possibly toxic 'back flow.' I put the bag in a wire mesh basket on the floor at the side of my chair, so I could just carry the entire thing to the bathroom when it was time to empty it. This also worked well while showering, as it was easy enough to set it down and not worry about the water, though I usually just hooked the bag to my shower door bar. In my case, I'm not normally a back sleeper, and I wasn't willing to risk that I wouldn't roll over onto that contraption! I was kind of forced to stay on my back this way. 5. When you returned home from the hospital, is there anything that you absolutely couldn't do by yourself and needed help with ? Reason I ask is because I live alone but can have a friend stop over once in a while. I was fine after I got home. And hungry! My wife checked on me, but I didn't really need any help. Hardly needed any pain meds, either. I was also given a respirator tube to blow in from time to time to be sure my lungs and all were working OK. I guess from the anesthesia. 6. What did you take to the hospital on your surgery day ? A large shirt and a pair of over sized sweat pants with elastic leg cuffs for discharge. I just wound the cath tube around my leg and dropped the bag down my pants leg. And my laptop/phone. Hopkins has wireless! I was also given a 'goodies bag' upon release with lubes, bandages, an extra cath bag, etc. but I didn't need that. Some guys got a small travel bag, but I didn't. Just more emptying, IMO. A nurse showed me some cleaning instructions, up close and personal, before discharge. Kind of embarrassing, and she looked to be about 70 years old! But, there's no dignity with this operation, so I just wanted to get out of there. And as I always say, be careful around cabinet and door knobs! I've read of many guys experiencing discomfort from the gas, but I didn't have that issue being an 'open' guy. Honestly, other than carrying that bag around and having a tube stuffed in my junk, I didn't have any real issues. Don't be surprised if your scrotum looks like a softball a few days out. I was! It eventually subsided though. Best of luck. You'll do fine. The worrying is the worst part. Ron

Posts.Content: Should I ask for an MRI first? In my opinion? Absolutely. 3T preferably. My first biopsy didn't find anything, as those things are really shooting blind and hoping to hit something. Well, often these tumors are quite small. Once I had my 3T MRI prior to my second biopsy, the doctor had a 'suspicious area' to target with the needles and this proved successful in my diagnoses.

Posts.Content: Yep, Paul. Aging gracefully: The big lie, lol! I'm hitting my 2 year mark a few days after yours. My ortho wants to do a bursitis clean up on both hips and gluteus tear repair. I'm just so tired of the surgery stuff, I keep putting it off. I swear. I'll turn 54 later this month, and sometimes I feel like I'm going on 74! I think my law enforcement career is catching up with me! Trips, falls, take-downs, body armor and heavy equipment everyday....ugh. Good times! Thank God I made it to retirement. Apparently, my wife wasn't as keen as I was on doing a few extra years! CONGRATS ON THE PSA! Ron

Posts.Title: RP the day before yesterday

Posts.Content: Welcome R2F. Hopefully this will just end up being a big bag of worrying for nothing for you and your husband. Curious though as to why you requested his getting a PSA at 48 (not that it's a bad thing as I think earlier should be the norm). Does your husband have a family history of PCa? The biopsy isn't that big of a deal, but if his doc is willing to give him a numbing gel prior to the numbing needle, I highly recommend that route. It's just a lubed finger up _there_ and it helps deaden the needle discomfort. The 12 core isn't perfect by any means. My first one missed. There are newer imaging methods coming about, but it seems many times that insurance won't cover their costs without a previous negative biopsy (though I find this logic skewed). If he could get a 3T MRI first that would be ideal, but then again, there's the insurance issue. Either way, only a biopsy can definitively rule out--or rule in--PCa, so he's going to likely have one no matter what. Again, not that big of a deal. My doc also prescribed a valium for the morning of the procedure, as well as an antibiotic. If your husband's hasn't done that, I'd ask....and if your husband's doc hasn't done that, and/or taken steps to rule out infection, frankly, I'd consider another doc! Could you place your location in your profile? It often helps the rest of us as we give suggestions. Edit: I now see that your husband doesn't know of his family history. Best of luck. Ron
