Posts.Title: Sky high PSA of 85 and Gleason 4+4

Posts.Content: Hi, Tim.... I had 'open' rather than 'robotic' but here ya go: 1. It seems as if a lot of men suffer from Bladder Spasm's due to having their catheter in. And some describe them as a constant urge to urinate and others describe it as an excruciating pain. I am curious how often this happens and how much of a problem this was for you? Be honest here. Also, if this did happen to you, did you find anything that brought them on and anything that minimized or eliminated them ? Thankfully, I never had this occur. Or if I did, I didn't know it. Either way, I'm good with that! 2. What will my diet be like following surgery and how long will it take to improve? I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? The day of surgery, I was on a liquid diet that evening post-op. Broth and Jello, I believe. The next day I was allowed oatmeal. Once I got home, it was recommended to take it lightly for a couple of days, but no real dietary restrictions. Scrambled eggs were fine. 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight. My surgery was around 7:15 a.m., but I had to be there to check in at 5:15 a.m. Ugh! And I had to do a Fleets enema before leaving the house. Nothing says "good times" like lying on the bathroom floor at 3:30 a.m. sticking a watery tube up your a......, well, you know! I was released to go home at around 4:30 p.m. the day after surgery. The CNP, who we met before the surgery, pulled my drain tube about an hour or so before discharge. 4. It seems the general advice is to sleep on a recliner rather than a bed following Robotic Prostatectomy. I am curious why this is and what is the actual thing that makes sleeping in a bed difficult ? Reason I ask is because I don't have a recliner. For those of you who didn't have a recliner, how did you manage sleeping ? Also, how long does it take (Days?) until you were able to sleep on a regular bed ? I also recommend a recliner, though other guys make a bed work. For one thing, you don't have to worry so much about rolling over on your cath tube. You also want to keep the cath bag below your bladder level to decrease the chances of possibly toxic 'back flow.' I put the bag in a wire mesh basket on the floor at the side of my chair, so I could just carry the entire thing to the bathroom when it was time to empty it. This also worked well while showering, as it was easy enough to set it down and not worry about the water, though I usually just hooked the bag to my shower door bar. In my case, I'm not normally a back sleeper, and I wasn't willing to risk that I wouldn't roll over onto that contraption! I was kind of forced to stay on my back this way. 5. When you returned home from the hospital, is there anything that you absolutely couldn't do by yourself and needed help with ? Reason I ask is because I live alone but can have a friend stop over once in a while. I was fine after I got home. And hungry! My wife checked on me, but I didn't really need any help. Hardly needed any pain meds, either. I was also given a respirator tube to blow in from time to time to be sure my lungs and all were working OK. I guess from the anesthesia. 6. What did you take to the hospital on your surgery day ? A large shirt and a pair of over sized sweat pants with elastic leg cuffs for discharge. I just wound the cath tube around my leg and dropped the bag down my pants leg. And my laptop/phone. Hopkins has wireless! I was also given a 'goodies bag' upon release with lubes, bandages, an extra cath bag, etc. but I didn't need that. Some guys got a small travel bag, but I didn't. Just more emptying, IMO. A nurse showed me some cleaning instructions, up close and personal, before discharge. Kind of embarrassing, and she looked to be about 70 years old! But, there's no dignity with this operation, so I just wanted to get out of there. And as I always say, be careful around cabinet and door knobs! I've read of many guys experiencing discomfort from the gas, but I didn't have that issue being an 'open' guy. Honestly, other than carrying that bag around and having a tube stuffed in my junk, I didn't have any real issues. Don't be surprised if your scrotum looks like a softball a few days out. I was! It eventually subsided though. Best of luck. You'll do fine. The worrying is the worst part. Ron

Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: Hi, Tim.... I had 'open' rather than 'robotic' but here ya go: 1. It seems as if a lot of men suffer from Bladder Spasm's due to having their catheter in. And some describe them as a constant urge to urinate and others describe it as an excruciating pain. I am curious how often this happens and how much of a problem this was for you? Be honest here. Also, if this did happen to you, did you find anything that brought them on and anything that minimized or eliminated them ? Thankfully, I never had this occur. Or if I did, I didn't know it. Either way, I'm good with that! 2. What will my diet be like following surgery and how long will it take to improve? I believe it is recommended to have a liquid diet following surgery but I am curious why this is, and how soon (days?) generally until I could have solid food ? The day of surgery, I was on a liquid diet that evening post-op. Broth and Jello, I believe. The next day I was allowed oatmeal. Once I got home, it was recommended to take it lightly for a couple of days, but no real dietary restrictions. Scrambled eggs were fine. 3. Am curious how long your hospital stay was and if there were any complications in your case ? I was told by a nurse 2-3 days but most everywhere I read seems to indicate only overnight. My surgery was around 7:15 a.m., but I had to be there to check in at 5:15 a.m. Ugh! And I had to do a Fleets enema before leaving the house. Nothing says "good times" like lying on the bathroom floor at 3:30 a.m. sticking a watery tube up your a......, well, you know! I was released to go home at around 4:30 p.m. the day after surgery. The CNP, who we met before the surgery, pulled my drain tube about an hour or so before discharge. 4. It seems the general advice is to sleep on a recliner rather than a bed following Robotic Prostatectomy. I am curious why this is and what is the actual thing that makes sleeping in a bed difficult ? Reason I ask is because I don't have a recliner. For those of you who didn't have a recliner, how did you manage sleeping ? Also, how long does it take (Days?) until you were able to sleep on a regular bed ? I also recommend a recliner, though other guys make a bed work. For one thing, you don't have to worry so much about rolling over on your cath tube. You also want to keep the cath bag below your bladder level to decrease the chances of possibly toxic 'back flow.' I put the bag in a wire mesh basket on the floor at the side of my chair, so I could just carry the entire thing to the bathroom when it was time to empty it. This also worked well while showering, as it was easy enough to set it down and not worry about the water, though I usually just hooked the bag to my shower door bar. In my case, I'm not normally a back sleeper, and I wasn't willing to risk that I wouldn't roll over onto that contraption! I was kind of forced to stay on my back this way. 5. When you returned home from the hospital, is there anything that you absolutely couldn't do by yourself and needed help with ? Reason I ask is because I live alone but can have a friend stop over once in a while. I was fine after I got home. And hungry! My wife checked on me, but I didn't really need any help. Hardly needed any pain meds, either. I was also given a respirator tube to blow in from time to time to be sure my lungs and all were working OK. I guess from the anesthesia. 6. What did you take to the hospital on your surgery day ? A large shirt and a pair of over sized sweat pants with elastic leg cuffs for discharge. I just wound the cath tube around my leg and dropped the bag down my pants leg. And my laptop/phone. Hopkins has wireless! I was also given a 'goodies bag' upon release with lubes, bandages, an extra cath bag, etc. but I didn't need that. Some guys got a small travel bag, but I didn't. Just more emptying, IMO. A nurse showed me some cleaning instructions, up close and personal, before discharge. Kind of embarrassing, and she looked to be about 70 years old! But, there's no dignity with this operation, so I just wanted to get out of there. And as I always say, be careful around cabinet and door knobs! I've read of many guys experiencing discomfort from the gas, but I didn't have that issue being an 'open' guy. Honestly, other than carrying that bag around and having a tube stuffed in my junk, I didn't have any real issues. Don't be surprised if your scrotum looks like a softball a few days out. I was! It eventually subsided though. Best of luck. You'll do fine. The worrying is the worst part. Ron

Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: So, I got my first issue of the 'Discovery' quarterly newsletter from Hopkins since my surgery. Pretty informative regarding PC and treatment developments. Aside from that, from what it's indicating, the new protocol regarding PC scores that were developed by Jonathan Epstein and presented at the American Urological Association meeting in New Orleans have been accepted by the World Health Organization and will be used in conjunction with the current Gleason system "until it becomes widely accepted and practiced." It seems he's trying to simplify and categorize things better. Grade Group 1: Gleason 3+3=6 Grade Group 2: Gleason 3+4=7 Grade Group 3: Gleason 4+3=7 Grade Group 4: Gleason 8 Grade Group 5: Gleason 9 & 10 Some may have already heard of this proposal, but this is the first I've heard of its acceptance. Seems the G7 needed to be clarified, as well as the fact that nothing lower than a G6 would be diagnosed anyways.

Posts.Title: New PCa grading system

Posts.Content: Hi Cubby. Just shouting out a big welcome to you as you've unfortunately found your way here! I'm running out the door to pick up my Viagra prescription (LOL!) but I'll mention that as far as checking your margins goes, and I assume you mean while you're still on the table having the surgeon running the prostate specimen over to pathology to examine the gland, I believe that to be surgeon-dependent. I don't think it's as common now (don't hold me to that!), maybe because surgical methods have gotten much more refined over the years. My doc did not do this, but I believe I've read on this forum of others that had this done. Have you had any imaging, like a MRI (3T) performed? As far as choosing goes, you'll probably get many responses to that. I was younger, at 51 when Dx'd and felt that I wanted it out and I didn't want to risk issues down the road with possible radiation side-effects (though these issues seem to be less of a problem as methods improve). While mine was 'only' a Gleason 6, it was on both sides/lobes and that made me a little uncomfortable. I also knew that until the gland was examined in pathology, I didn't really know what may be lurking in there. Turns out it was 3+4=7. There are more treatment options coming to bear now and they seem promising. I'll let others more knowledgeable than myself comment on them. I'm coming up on 9 months post-op and doing well, all things considered. If you'd like, you can post your 'history' over the years in your signature section, as well as your location in your profile. Then we don't have to keep pestering you with those questions. Best wishes, Ron

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Hi Cubby. Just shouting out a big welcome to you as you've unfortunately found your way here! I'm running out the door to pick up my Viagra prescription (LOL!) but I'll mention that as far as checking your margins goes, and I assume you mean while you're still on the table having the surgeon running the prostate specimen over to pathology to examine the gland, I believe that to be surgeon-dependent. I don't think it's as common now (don't hold me to that!), maybe because surgical methods have gotten much more refined over the years. My doc did not do this, but I believe I've read on this forum of others that had this done. Have you had any imaging, like a MRI (3T) performed? As far as choosing goes, you'll probably get many responses to that. I was younger, at 51 when Dx'd and felt that I wanted it out and I didn't want to risk issues down the road with possible radiation side-effects (though these issues seem to be less of a problem as methods improve). While mine was 'only' a Gleason 6, it was on both sides/lobes and that made me a little uncomfortable. I also knew that until the gland was examined in pathology, I didn't really know what may be lurking in there. Turns out it was 3+4=7. There are more treatment options coming to bear now and they seem promising. I'll let others more knowledgeable than myself comment on them. I'm coming up on 9 months post-op and doing well, all things considered. If you'd like, you can post your 'history' over the years in your signature section, as well as your location in your profile. Then we don't have to keep pestering you with those questions. Best wishes, Ron

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed and weighing my options

Posts.Content: Welcome R2F. Hopefully this will just end up being a big bag of worrying for nothing for you and your husband. Curious though as to why you requested his getting a PSA at 48 (not that it's a bad thing as I think earlier should be the norm). Does your husband have a family history of PCa? The biopsy isn't that big of a deal, but if his doc is willing to give him a numbing gel prior to the numbing needle, I highly recommend that route. It's just a lubed finger up _there_ and it helps deaden the needle discomfort. The 12 core isn't perfect by any means. My first one missed. There are newer imaging methods coming about, but it seems many times that insurance won't cover their costs without a previous negative biopsy (though I find this logic skewed). If he could get a 3T MRI first that would be ideal, but then again, there's the insurance issue. Either way, only a biopsy can definitively rule out--or rule in--PCa, so he's going to likely have one no matter what. Again, not that big of a deal. My doc also prescribed a valium for the morning of the procedure, as well as an antibiotic. If your husband's hasn't done that, I'd ask....and if your husband's doc hasn't done that, and/or taken steps to rule out infection, frankly, I'd consider another doc! Could you place your location in your profile? It often helps the rest of us as we give suggestions. Edit: I now see that your husband doesn't know of his family history. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Content: Yep, Paul. Aging gracefully: The big lie, lol! I'm hitting my 2 year mark a few days after yours. My ortho wants to do a bursitis clean up on both hips and gluteus tear repair. I'm just so tired of the surgery stuff, I keep putting it off. I swear. I'll turn 54 later this month, and sometimes I feel like I'm going on 74! I think my law enforcement career is catching up with me! Trips, falls, take-downs, body armor and heavy equipment everyday....ugh. Good times! Thank God I made it to retirement. Apparently, my wife wasn't as keen as I was on doing a few extra years! CONGRATS ON THE PSA! Ron

Posts.Title: What a week --but still in zero club

Posts.Content: Experience with Spaceoar Gel Diagnosis: Gleason 4+3, several tissue samples with cancer cells. Therapy: Radiation About 3 weeks ago the gel was injected between prostate and colon as a shield to protect colon from radiation. Radiation is underway now. This gel is a new development ho help reduce radiation side efects. Problem: Spaceoar Gel apparently to low positioned and eventually some gel in the injection cannula holes. Situation: Permanent pain in the perineum area between scrotum and anus. Very uncomfortable. This gel gets hard right after the injection. Now it is pressing hard and rubbing permanently from the inside. No seating for lunch or dinner, no car driving. Pain is always there. Gel gets dissolved and disappears apparently after 2-3 months. I can't imagine waiting so long with that pain. Any experience with such a situation or any advice? Thank you Chuck, found his only other post from a couple years ago. Makes me wonder if it's the gel that was supposed to dissolve/disappear. I've never heard of this gel, not being a radiation guy (at least not yet!).

Posts.Title: One year anniversary.

Posts.Content: Welcome R2F. Hopefully this will just end up being a big bag of worrying for nothing for you and your husband. Curious though as to why you requested his getting a PSA at 48 (not that it's a bad thing as I think earlier should be the norm). Does your husband have a family history of PCa? The biopsy isn't that big of a deal, but if his doc is willing to give him a numbing gel prior to the numbing needle, I highly recommend that route. It's just a lubed finger up _there_ and it helps deaden the needle discomfort. The 12 core isn't perfect by any means. My first one missed. There are newer imaging methods coming about, but it seems many times that insurance won't cover their costs without a previous negative biopsy (though I find this logic skewed). If he could get a 3T MRI first that would be ideal, but then again, there's the insurance issue. Either way, only a biopsy can definitively rule out--or rule in--PCa, so he's going to likely have one no matter what. Again, not that big of a deal. My doc also prescribed a valium for the morning of the procedure, as well as an antibiotic. If your husband's hasn't done that, I'd ask....and if your husband's doc hasn't done that, and/or taken steps to rule out infection, frankly, I'd consider another doc! Could you place your location in your profile? It often helps the rest of us as we give suggestions. Edit: I now see that your husband doesn't know of his family history. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Content: Cathy, just taking a shot with the limited info, but by "6 on a scale of 1 to 10" I think you're referring to the Gleason Scale scoring system. A Gleason '6' is about as low risk prostate cancer as one would be unfortunate enough to get, and is very treatable. Often treatment isn't even necessary. The 'C' word' is always scary, but try to relax a bit. When you get a chance, could you provide some more details? Biopsy results, his age and PSA history, Gleason score, etc. Your location would also be helpful. Many of these can be added to your profile and/or signature line. Hang in there, Ron

Posts.Title: 43 years young and joining the Club

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. The PSA results were uploaded to 'MyChart' this morning. <0.1---whew! MM--thanks. I know I should be OK, especially with my path report, but then I'll see someone on one of these sites that should've been 'OK' also--and he's not. Everything being contained was a blessing, especially as I went into this blindsided, and what I blew off as a routine blood draw at the time changed my life. I believe my uncle has made it about 19 years now post-surgery w/o any type of recurrence issues. I realize that you've had a much tougher hand dealt to you and you're not that much older than me. I wish you, and all the forum brothers (and their significant others) well in their journeys. Jim--LOL! That whole thing with your lungs is just crazy. I hope you're as lucky at the poker table! Maybe I'll go out and buy a lottery ticket today. When I checked in at JH to have my blood drawn, I was given a number---13! I was like....."really?!" Jimbow--My urine stream seems fine. I didn't have a significantly enlarged prostate prior to surgery, so I can't say that's it better than before, but I haven't had any issues--though sometimes the pattern seems a bit wider than I would like, LOL! My primary doc will likely take over the PSA testing at this point. Dr. Carter told me that barring any concerns, we don't have to have our every 3 month follow-up phone calls anymore. Because of this, my next PSA check will probably be in a little over 4 months rather than 6--the timing of the appointment and such. So, I'll try and relax until then. Best to all, Ron

Posts.Title: Is it possible?

Posts.Content: Hi Marve. Do I understand that this upcoming biopsy will be the 4th that your uncle is being subjected to? I wouldn't even wish that on someone I don't like! I agree with Chuck. IMO, your Uncle should be pursuing treatment options, not be scheduled for another biopsy. The cancer has already been located. What else are they hoping for? IMO, that there was no cancer on biopsy #3 simply means the doctor missed it with the needles because the cancer found the first 2 times didn't just go away! If your uncle's doctor missed cancer the last time, what if he is missing cancer that is more serious than Gleason 6? Frankly, with 5 total cores positive I believe he should've already had treatment recommended, unless, as Chuck said, the doctor is under some type of strict protocol that doesn't give him many treatment options at this point. Is this your father's brother?

Posts.Content: Check this link:http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm It states 5-7 days after receipt of slides for diagnosis. I believe it's about $250 if insurance won't cover it, but from what I've read, well worth the peace of mind (I live in Maryland and used JH; Epstein reviewed my biopsy after the resident did and concurred). You're going to have a few weeks post biopsy to start any treatment anyways, so why not have the review while you're waiting??

Posts.Title: 43 years young and joining the Club

Posts.Content: Hi Marve. Do I understand that this upcoming biopsy will be the 4th that your uncle is being subjected to? I wouldn't even wish that on someone I don't like! I agree with Chuck. IMO, your Uncle should be pursuing treatment options, not be scheduled for another biopsy. The cancer has already been located. What else are they hoping for? IMO, that there was no cancer on biopsy #3 simply means the doctor missed it with the needles because the cancer found the first 2 times didn't just go away! If your uncle's doctor missed cancer the last time, what if he is missing cancer that is more serious than Gleason 6? Frankly, with 5 total cores positive I believe he should've already had treatment recommended, unless, as Chuck said, the doctor is under some type of strict protocol that doesn't give him many treatment options at this point. Is this your father's brother?

Posts.Title: Small step for mankind big step for me...

Posts.Content: Brava, I had rotator cuff surgery back in 2012. I told myself that if I could survive that recovery, I could survive anything--and it was outpatient! Unfortunately, I had to test my theory with the RP surgery (also 51 yoa). Thinking about it now, I still think the rotator cuff was worse in the recovery aspect. Sometimes I'd get these really awful shooting pains in my upper arm and I slept in a recliner for 6 weeks with a big sling on. Then physical therapy..... The RP surgery is major stuff, don't get me wrong, but really the recovery wasn't so bad. The catheter is a PITA, but it's a temporary annoyance more than anything. And I actually enjoyed my first and only overnight hospital stay at Hopkins. Private room, TV, little green button I got to push every 10 minutes for my pain meds (probably didn't even need it, but why risk it?!), and I didn't have any barking dogs and crazy cats like I do at home. I wouldn't have minded an extra night! Have you posted your location? You can add that to your profile. Goof luck, Ron

Posts.Title: Metal Hips, MRI and the Woody

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. The PSA results were uploaded to 'MyChart' this morning. <0.1---whew! MM--thanks. I know I should be OK, especially with my path report, but then I'll see someone on one of these sites that should've been 'OK' also--and he's not. Everything being contained was a blessing, especially as I went into this blindsided, and what I blew off as a routine blood draw at the time changed my life. I believe my uncle has made it about 19 years now post-surgery w/o any type of recurrence issues. I realize that you've had a much tougher hand dealt to you and you're not that much older than me. I wish you, and all the forum brothers (and their significant others) well in their journeys. Jim--LOL! That whole thing with your lungs is just crazy. I hope you're as lucky at the poker table! Maybe I'll go out and buy a lottery ticket today. When I checked in at JH to have my blood drawn, I was given a number---13! I was like....."really?!" Jimbow--My urine stream seems fine. I didn't have a significantly enlarged prostate prior to surgery, so I can't say that's it better than before, but I haven't had any issues--though sometimes the pattern seems a bit wider than I would like, LOL! My primary doc will likely take over the PSA testing at this point. Dr. Carter told me that barring any concerns, we don't have to have our every 3 month follow-up phone calls anymore. Because of this, my next PSA check will probably be in a little over 4 months rather than 6--the timing of the appointment and such. So, I'll try and relax until then. Best to all, Ron

Posts.Title: So, tomorrow is my 9 month surgery anniversary.....

Posts.Content: Sometimes I can't believe it has been that long. Other than the occasional 'squirt' (often just a 'ghost squirt'--nothing happened) I'm mostly back to normal. I appreciate what women mean more now when they say "I have to go--now!" since I don't have that prostate thing helping me out any more. lol! Erections are pretty good, though I admit I miss the 'fluid' aspect more than I thought I would. I usually have a shield at night, or if I go out to something formal, just in case. Usually dry though. Ran up to Johns Hopkins to get my PSA blood draw today. Probably have the results in a day or so. I guess this PSA anxiety will eventually wane, too. Blood tech was nice--and cute--so that's always a good thing! I try to think of the alternatives when I feel down about this stuff..... Good night all...... Ron

Posts.Title: PSA angst....

Posts.Content: Anotherpc---sorry about you having to join us, and at only 39 (WTF?!). Please do get a 2nd opinion on your biopsy slides, and ask to have the slides sent to Dr. Epstein at Johns Hopkins. He's the expert. Those low PSAs with G9 suggest the need for quick action. I wish all the best for you. Maybe Epstein will (hopefully) have a different view and a downgrade. Please check your biopsy report when you get it for 'adenocarcinoma' vs. the 'intraductal' (IDC-P) variety. The latter seems to be more aggressive with a lower PSA while a higher Gleason score. If that's the case, you'll want to begin researching experts in that treatment field. Good (great) luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Lupron & Casodex Discontinuance?

Posts.Content: Zen, first of all, best wishes and sorry you're here to begin with. Secondly, as Michael has already touched on, what are you hoping to gain with a 2nd opinion read? With your amount of cores (no matter whether G6 or G7), and percentage of involvement, as well as PNI and likely being bilateral, treatment seems in your future. Of course, it's your money and the $250 2nd opinion fee seems correct. I believe the fee you're looking at is for more services. I was confused by this the first time I saw it, but since I went to JH anyways, it didn't matter in my case. Best of luck, Ron

Posts.Content: Check this link:http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm It states 5-7 days after receipt of slides for diagnosis. I believe it's about $250 if insurance won't cover it, but from what I've read, well worth the peace of mind (I live in Maryland and used JH; Epstein reviewed my biopsy after the resident did and concurred). You're going to have a few weeks post biopsy to start any treatment anyways, so why not have the review while you're waiting??

Posts.Content: Anotherpc---sorry about you having to join us, and at only 39 (WTF?!). Please do get a 2nd opinion on your biopsy slides, and ask to have the slides sent to Dr. Epstein at Johns Hopkins. He's the expert. Those low PSAs with G9 suggest the need for quick action. I wish all the best for you. Maybe Epstein will (hopefully) have a different view and a downgrade. Please check your biopsy report when you get it for 'adenocarcinoma' vs. the 'intraductal' (IDC-P) variety. The latter seems to be more aggressive with a lower PSA while a higher Gleason score. If that's the case, you'll want to begin researching experts in that treatment field. Good (great) luck. Ron

Posts.Content: Brava, I had rotator cuff surgery back in 2012. I told myself that if I could survive that recovery, I could survive anything--and it was outpatient! Unfortunately, I had to test my theory with the RP surgery (also 51 yoa). Thinking about it now, I still think the rotator cuff was worse in the recovery aspect. Sometimes I'd get these really awful shooting pains in my upper arm and I slept in a recliner for 6 weeks with a big sling on. Then physical therapy..... The RP surgery is major stuff, don't get me wrong, but really the recovery wasn't so bad. The catheter is a PITA, but it's a temporary annoyance more than anything. And I actually enjoyed my first and only overnight hospital stay at Hopkins. Private room, TV, little green button I got to push every 10 minutes for my pain meds (probably didn't even need it, but why risk it?!), and I didn't have any barking dogs and crazy cats like I do at home. I wouldn't have minded an extra night! Have you posted your location? You can add that to your profile. Goof luck, Ron

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Wilde, what do mean with "dirty"? He probably means your husband will probably have to do a colon cleansing routine like before a colonoscopy. I believe that's pretty standard with robotic surgery. My surgery was of the 'open' type thus all I needed was a Fleets enema the morning of. I. too, decided a recliner was the way to go. Sleeping soundly is somewhat a problem and the catheter is a nuisance. The bag has to be below the bladder at all times to prevent potentially toxic 'backflow' so I just set it in a bucket on the floor beside me as I slept (or tried to sleep).

Posts.Content: Hi, Chuck and Davis. The AS route is apparently dependent on the facility. While my numbers would seem to fit the bill, mine being bi-lateral disqualified me from the program at Hopkins. Davis' stats seem to indicate his is bilateral, too. I assume that having the disease on both sides, even while low grade, is more risky than if the 2 cores were on one side--unilateral--only. I'm not saying that it can't be done, only it seems facility dependent.

Posts.Title: Prolaris Scoring

Posts.Content: Hi John. Welcome..... That's indeed a pretty sharp increase in 2 months. Any chance you may have done anything to your prostate just prior to the last PSA? Infection? Bike riding, sex, did the doc perform a DRE (finger wave) prior to the test? That's still a good jump, but just thinking out loud I guess...... Back to the question. I was biopsied the second time and Dx in March '14. I asked my surgeon what type of window should I be looking at regarding surgery dates, and he said I don't have to rush, but I might want to keep it to within 6 months. I had surgery in August, 5 months later. My Dx was a G6 also, and my pre-surgery PSA was lower at 5.7. Personally, I'd take the trip. She deserves it after putting up with you for 43 years, LOL! I kid, I kid..... If the chief urologist isn't concerned, I wouldn't be too much. Besides, nothing is going to get done before your next PSA in March anyways. Maybe just go with that and see what happens? I don't know if it's possible for you, but many here would recommend that you get a 3T mp-MRI. It can show if it looks like anything is involving your lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, or if anything appears to have escaped your prostate. It may help your piece of mind in the meantime. Maybe check with your doc about this and see what he thinks? Were your prior PSAs before the 4.7 elevated also? Good luck. Ron

Posts.Content: ...lube the tip of the catheter at the end of your Johnson. You can even pull out the catheter tube about a quarter inch or so. When pulled out, lube the tube, then push it back inside your Johnson to better lube yourself. That is far better then just lubing the very tip of your Johnson. LOL. I had a 60+ something year old woman showing me how to do this before I was discharged. Embarrassing!!!!! But, I knew I'd have no humility left by the time I got home.

Posts.Title: Concerned Wife

Posts.Content: Hi John. Welcome..... That's indeed a pretty sharp increase in 2 months. Any chance you may have done anything to your prostate just prior to the last PSA? Infection? Bike riding, sex, did the doc perform a DRE (finger wave) prior to the test? That's still a good jump, but just thinking out loud I guess...... Back to the question. I was biopsied the second time and Dx in March '14. I asked my surgeon what type of window should I be looking at regarding surgery dates, and he said I don't have to rush, but I might want to keep it to within 6 months. I had surgery in August, 5 months later. My Dx was a G6 also, and my pre-surgery PSA was lower at 5.7. Personally, I'd take the trip. She deserves it after putting up with you for 43 years, LOL! I kid, I kid..... If the chief urologist isn't concerned, I wouldn't be too much. Besides, nothing is going to get done before your next PSA in March anyways. Maybe just go with that and see what happens? I don't know if it's possible for you, but many here would recommend that you get a 3T mp-MRI. It can show if it looks like anything is involving your lymph nodes, seminal vesicles, or if anything appears to have escaped your prostate. It may help your piece of mind in the meantime. Maybe check with your doc about this and see what he thinks? Were your prior PSAs before the 4.7 elevated also? Good luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Surgery wait time

Posts.Content: Wilde, what do mean with "dirty"? He probably means your husband will probably have to do a colon cleansing routine like before a colonoscopy. I believe that's pretty standard with robotic surgery. My surgery was of the 'open' type thus all I needed was a Fleets enema the morning of. I. too, decided a recliner was the way to go. Sleeping soundly is somewhat a problem and the catheter is a nuisance. The bag has to be below the bladder at all times to prevent potentially toxic 'backflow' so I just set it in a bucket on the floor beside me as I slept (or tried to sleep).

Posts.Title: Concerned Wife

Posts.Content: Mav-- luckily, you really don't have to be in a rush. At your age, surgery has been the 'standard' for quite some time now, though I realize treatments evolve. When I asked my doc about radiation he didn't tell me I was crazy or anything, but he mentioned the possibility of other cancers as a result of radiation, like bladder, urethral, etc. It IS radiation after all! If I was a bit older, I'd likely outlive those risks. At my age of 51 at the time, hmmm......just don't know. Regarding surgery after radiation? Well, as you said, surgery may still be an option. But if not? And one big thing about surgery is that you don't really know how aggressive your cancer is until the pathologist has it under the 'scope, which surgery confirms. Tough decisions. We've been there. Good luck! Ron

And be careful around cabinet knobs with that tube! As far as the bag, I just dropped it down inside my oversized sweatpants leg when I walked, though sometimes, when I went out for an evening stroll, I placed it inside a shopping bag. Posts.Content: Welcome back, bro. Too bad it's with the news you'd rather not hear, but you needed to know. As you're already aware, you'll get arguments for/against both, and it certainly doesn't hurt to speak to the radiation docs in additions to the surgeons, but you're a young guy, and the benefit of removal is that the final pathology will give you your true Gleason score, and removal may help clear up some other prostate-related issues you may have......just my 2 cents. Obviously AS isn't an option. Best of luck on your decision. Ron

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Welcome PecenkA. I was curious , too, so I looked around. Seems like a good thing. If surgical margins are positive for tumor (residual microscopic disease), staging is modified by an "R1" descriptor in contrast to negative margins "R0." I don't think negative margins are usually noted, other than just being 'negative.'

Posts.Title: Dad's post op diagnosis question

Posts.Content: Mav-- luckily, you really don't have to be in a rush. At your age, surgery has been the 'standard' for quite some time now, though I realize treatments evolve. When I asked my doc about radiation he didn't tell me I was crazy or anything, but he mentioned the possibility of other cancers as a result of radiation, like bladder, urethral, etc. It IS radiation after all! If I was a bit older, I'd likely outlive those risks. At my age of 51 at the time, hmmm......just don't know. Regarding surgery after radiation? Well, as you said, surgery may still be an option. But if not? And one big thing about surgery is that you don't really know how aggressive your cancer is until the pathologist has it under the 'scope, which surgery confirms. Tough decisions. We've been there. Good luck! Ron

Posts.Content: Welcome back, bro. Too bad it's with the news you'd rather not hear, but you needed to know. As you're already aware, you'll get arguments for/against both, and it certainly doesn't hurt to speak to the radiation docs in additions to the surgeons, but you're a young guy, and the benefit of removal is that the final pathology will give you your true Gleason score, and removal may help clear up some other prostate-related issues you may have......just my 2 cents. Obviously AS isn't an option. Best of luck on your decision. Ron

Posts.Title: What to do if PSA Level is High

Posts.Content: Good luck, Gary. If your experience is close to mine at Johns Hopkins, you'll be discharged the day after your surgery sometime after 4:00 p.m. Your drain tube should be removed shortly before that. Also expect a lesson from a nurse who will show you the proper way to clean and lube the catheter tube. I think my nurse was about 70 years old, lol! But hey. You'll have no dignity left by that time anyways! I only received the large catheter drain bag. While I can't say if it's normal at JH, but when I asked the nurse she said something about them only sending you home with that one bag. You should also receive a 'goodie bag' before discharge containing an extra, large catheter bag (I never needed it), swabs, lubes, antibiotic ointments, creams, gauze, etc. Something else to think about as you're packing up to go back home on the plane, too. I had open surgery rather than robotic, and I was fine pain wise from the night I got home, really. Another thing that I found out after my surgery: Apparently I'm 'TSA-prone' now! The first time I flew post-surgery, and out of BWI at that, I got pulled to the side after going through the scanner and hand-wanded. That's never happened before. I couldn't figure out why until I had a hip xray a bit later and the tech asked "have you ever had any surgery, like maybe around your prostate?" What? Well, after getting a look, it's a bit odd in there now. IDK if it's the suturing or staples, but a bunch of white lines were clearly visible. Hope I'm not on the 'watch list' now! Not sure of your BWI experience, but just be aware that it can get busy. I never thought to ask before, but as I was taking my elderly father-in-law through the last time and staring at long lines at the TSA checkpoint, I mentioned his problems with standing a long time to the TSA agent and she let us through the rope and through the scanners. Awesome! I was also able to obtain a 'pass' that allowed me to assist him as far as the gate for his flight (in case you need extra assistance). All in all, I had a great experience at JH. I awoke in recovery and stayed until a room was available. It was a private room in the Sheikh Zayed Tower on the 11th floor. I didn't have any barking dogs or crazy cats to put up with for one night in my life, and I had a little green button to push every 10 minutes for pain if I needed it. I only remember being awakened once overnight by a nurse checking/replacing things. My own TV and wi-fi is available if you're up to it. Be sure to grab a crab cake before leaving town! Ron

Posts.Title: Man cured of prostate cancer after being given testosterone to shock tumors

Posts.Content: It's out! , mikeg. I'll take your word for it. This morning has come and gone and the catheter removal was AWESOME! I told my wife as we were leaving Hopkins that I felt like we were forgetting something...... It felt a bit strange upon removal, but nothing painful. I enjoyed a couple Cap'n Morgan & Cokes last night because I figured I'd have to be more mindful of alcohol consumption once I got rid of my 'bathroom buddy!" Unfortunately, I had a bit of a monkey wrench tossed at me. The incision site in my lower abdomen has apparently developed a bit of an infection. It's been a bit red and sore, but I just wrote that off to irritation from the waistband of my pants/shorts rubbing against the area. So, no surgical staple removal today. I pulled on my man-diaper, was put on antibiotics, and off to home I went. We'll try again Friday. Side note: I got to try using a toilet for the first time in 12 days. I did it! LOL!!! I was a little damp--from dribbles no doubt--in my diaper after getting home. I felt like I had to 'go' and gave it a try. Hey, it still works! The nurse suggested that I try to hold my stream as I'm urinating to get into practice. I tried it and I was able to stop the flow, albeit not nearly as quickly as before the surgery, but it's a (hopeful) start. Now that I say this, just watch. Tomorrow I'll be peeing all over myself! Well, back to the Kegels!

Posts.Content: Awesome Dave. If you're near Columbia, you aren't far from me. I also had a great experience after open RP at JH. I remember being wheeled down the hallway towards surgery, and as the hallway was becoming colder as I neared my destination, thinking about making a break for it! Dr. H. Ballentine Carter was recommended to me there by a friend of my wife's friend who is a scientist there. I'm glad a switched from the local uro group. I liked the first doc and all, but as much as I complain about living in Maryland, having Johns Hopkins 30 minutes away isn't one of those reasons! Dr. Carter gave me the option of removing the catheter myself, but I figured I had to go back and have the abdominal staples removed anyways. I suppose if someone comes from a great distance it's a viable option. The only real issue I had was an apparent skin reaction to the staples, which delayed their removal a couple of days. Good luck on your pending entry into the 'Zero Club!' Ron

Posts.Title: My PC Journey So Far

Posts.Content: I saw that my path report was uploaded to my Johns Hopkins online 'chart' but I knew I was going to be speaking with my surgeon, Dr. Carter, about the report this morning so I refused to look at it until after that discussion. No point in potentially getting myself worked up over things I may misinterpret, right? So, good news all in all. Disease was prostate confined. Nothing had spread to the lymph nodes or seminal vesicles--whew!!! I updated my signature with the results. I believe my decision to have surgery was reaffirmed with the upgrade to a Gleason 7, albeit the (3+4) variety and only 2% involvement, but anything above a GS 6 was going to cause me stress! So, the adage rings true: We really don't know what we have until it's out and under a microscope. Well, that was the climax of the weekend.....what do we do now??!! I'll see Dr. Carter next Wednesday when I get these staples out of my abdomen and get rid of this damn catheter! I guess my next sweat will be my next PSA, but Dr. Carter told me I'm over-worrying myself as I should be fine.....yeah, easy for him to say! I think I'll have a few drinks this weekend to celebrate. Catheter bag: Do your duty! Thanks for the positive vibes everybody. They were much appreciated!

If your experience is close to mine at Johns Hopkins, you'll be discharged the day after your surgery sometime after 4:00 p.m. Your drain tube should be removed shortly before that. Also expect a lesson from a nurse who will show you the proper way to clean and lube the catheter tube. I think my nurse was about 70 years old, lol! But hey. You'll have no dignity left by that time anyways! I only received the large catheter drain bag. While I can't say if it's normal at JH, but when I asked the nurse she said something about them only sending you home with that one bag. You should also receive a 'goodie bag' before discharge containing an extra, large catheter bag (I never needed it), swabs, lubes, antibiotic ointments, creams, gauze, etc. Something else to think about as you're packing up to go back home on the plane, too. I had open surgery rather than robotic, and I was fine pain wise from the night I got home, really. Another thing that I found out after my surgery: Apparently I'm 'TSA-prone' now! The first time I flew post-surgery, and out of BWI at that, I got pulled to the side after going through the scanner and hand-wanded. That's never happened before. I couldn't figure out why until I had a hip xray a bit later and the tech asked "have you ever had any surgery, like maybe around your prostate?" What? Well, after getting a look, it's a bit odd in there now. IDK if it's the suturing or staples, but a bunch of white lines were clearly visible. Hope I'm not on the 'watch list' now! Not sure of your BWI experience, but just be aware that it can get busy. I never thought to ask before, but as I was taking my elderly father-in-law through the last time and staring at long lines at the TSA checkpoint, I mentioned his problems with standing a long time to the TSA agent and she let us through the rope and through the scanners. Awesome! I was also able to obtain a 'pass' that allowed me to assist him as far as the gate for his flight (in case you need extra assistance). All in all, I had a great experience at JH. I awoke in recovery and stayed until a room was available. It was a private room in the Sheikh Zayed Tower on the 11th floor. I didn't have any barking dogs or crazy cats to put up with for one night in my life, and I had a little green button to push every 10 minutes for pain if I needed it. I only remember being awakened once overnight by a nurse checking/replacing things. My own TV and wi-fi is available if you're up to it. Be sure to grab a crab cake before leaving town! Ron

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: I saw that my path report was uploaded to my Johns Hopkins online 'chart' but I knew I was going to be speaking with my surgeon, Dr. Carter, about the report this morning so I refused to look at it until after that discussion. No point in potentially getting myself worked up over things I may misinterpret, right? So, good news all in all. Disease was prostate confined. Nothing had spread to the lymph nodes or seminal vesicles--whew!!! I updated my signature with the results. I believe my decision to have surgery was reaffirmed with the upgrade to a Gleason 7, albeit the (3+4) variety and only 2% involvement, but anything above a GS 6 was going to cause me stress! So, the adage rings true: We really don't know what we have until it's out and under a microscope. Well, that was the climax of the weekend.....what do we do now??!! I'll see Dr. Carter next Wednesday when I get these staples out of my abdomen and get rid of this damn catheter! I guess my next sweat will be my next PSA, but Dr. Carter told me I'm over-worrying myself as I should be fine.....yeah, easy for him to say! I think I'll have a few drinks this weekend to celebrate. Catheter bag: Do your duty! Thanks for the positive vibes everybody. They were much appreciated!

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: It's out! , mikeg. I'll take your word for it. This morning has come and gone and the catheter removal was AWESOME! I told my wife as we were leaving Hopkins that I felt like we were forgetting something...... It felt a bit strange upon removal, but nothing painful. I enjoyed a couple Cap'n Morgan & Cokes last night because I figured I'd have to be more mindful of alcohol consumption once I got rid of my 'bathroom buddy!" Unfortunately, I had a bit of a monkey wrench tossed at me. The incision site in my lower abdomen has apparently developed a bit of an infection. It's been a bit red and sore, but I just wrote that off to irritation from the waistband of my pants/shorts rubbing against the area. So, no surgical staple removal today. I pulled on my man-diaper, was put on antibiotics, and off to home I went. We'll try again Friday. Side note: I got to try using a toilet for the first time in 12 days. I did it! LOL!!! I was a little damp--from dribbles no doubt--in my diaper after getting home. I felt like I had to 'go' and gave it a try. Hey, it still works! The nurse suggested that I try to hold my stream as I'm urinating to get into practice. I tried it and I was able to stop the flow, albeit not nearly as quickly as before the surgery, but it's a (hopeful) start. Now that I say this, just watch. Tomorrow I'll be peeing all over myself! Well, back to the Kegels!

Posts.Title: Pathology report is back -- Relief!

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, Welcome Tom. Personally, my opinion with G6 cancer is you shouldn't be rushed into a decision, but with 4 cores @ 25%, you're gonna need some type of treatment in your semi-near future. Just tossing this out there, but Johns Hopkins is what, about 90 minutes--or less--from Philly? It may be worth considering for a second look. I can't help with your treatment decision, but I chose surgery at JH and am doing well. Other forum brothers have had similar experiences there. As far as logistics, when I made my appointment with the surgeon for a consultation regarding my treatment options, he told me that it would be about 2 months out for scheduling. In the end it was closer to 3, but I procrastinated until my wife put her foot down, LOL! My doc is sort of 'in demand' too, so that may have mattered. Day of surgery you'll get there to check in (5:15 am, for me!) and they rolled me back about 7:30 or so. I met the doc while I was having my IV inserted and some blood drawn in pre-op. My wife was allowed to stay with me for all this, until I was rolled away. After unsuccessfully trying to convince the young fella rolling me down the hallway to stop neat the elevator so I could make a run for it , I entered the OR and met the doc again as well as the surgical staff----then I woke up in recovery! That was about 3 hours later (my surgery was 'open' rather than robotic, so my understanding is that the procedure is a little faster with an experienced surgeon, thus you're not 'out' as long---everyone's mileage varies!). Then I waited for a room (private room in the new tower at Hopkins. Very peaceful.) I was discharged late the next afternoon/early evening (around 4:00 pm I think). For most, it's a one night hospital stay. You can go home after release, though you'll need a driver. You'll have your 'dancing partner' with you, AKA, the catheter, for about 10 days total. I was given the option of removing it myself (Um, no!) but I'm not too far from the hospital so they can do it! Apparently since many folks come to JH from all over, it's an option for some. Doc said he'd send me home with a syringe for the saline. If you decided on a hotel room, you'd likely only need it the night before surgery. Or not at all, if you'd be willing to leave very early the morning of surgery. You'll have to have a 'pre-surgery' visit to get cleared by the anesthesiology department shortly prior to surgery. This took about 1.5-2 hours. You'll also have to have a 'pre-op' visit with your primary care doc to fill out the paperwork for that. My understanding is hospitals used to admit you a day early for that pre-check stuff, but insurance companies got involved, so no more! A Google for 'Johns Hopkins Accommodations' revealed info on hotel discounts near the hospital. Disclaimer: This was my experience specifically related to JH, not everyone's was the same obviously. Good luck! Ron

Posts.Content: mjimsr--I know how your wife feels. My stepfather's wasn't found until too late, but mainly because of incompetent docs where he was living at the time. And this was in the modern era--he passed in April after a tough, 6 year battle. No family history, but agent orange exposure in 'Nam. His was a Gleason 8 and already out of the can when discovered. I have little doubt this is what contributed to my wife's constant pestering of me! LOL!

Posts.Title: Another new club member

Posts.Content: Hi Mj. I admire your 'just get it over with' frame of mind. A Gleason 6 isn't considered an aggressive cancer, so waiting shouldn't cause any physical risks. I was a bit more of the opposite. When I got my Dx back in March '15, I asked my doc how long I could wait?! He said I was at a low risk, but I may want to look inside a 6 month window. I lasted about a month after that appointment before my wife finally got aggravated with me about putting off making the surgery date and finally forced my hand! I still didn't have the surgery until August, but that was nearly 5 months I waited--and everything seems to have turned out well, surgically-wise. Good luck! PS. Can you provide your location?

This took about 1.5-2 hours. You'll also have to have a 'pre-op' visit with your primary care doc to fill out the paperwork for that. My understanding is hospitals used to admit you a day early for that pre-check stuff, but insurance companies got involved, so no more! A Google for 'Johns Hopkins Accommodations' revealed info on hotel discounts near the hospital. Disclaimer: This was my experience specifically related to JH, not everyone's was the same obviously. Good luck! Ron

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Recently

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, Welcome Tom. Personally, my opinion with G6 cancer is you shouldn't be rushed into a decision, but with 4 cores @ 25%, you're gonna need some type of treatment in your semi-near future. Just tossing this out there, but Johns Hopkins is what, about 90 minutes--or less--from Philly? It may be worth considering for a second look. I can't help with your treatment decision, but I chose surgery at JH and am doing well. Other forum brothers have had similar experiences there. As far as logistics, when I made my appointment with the surgeon for a consultation regarding my treatment options, he told me that it would be about 2 months out for scheduling. In the end it was closer to 3, but I procrastinated until my wife put her foot down, LOL! My doc is sort of 'in demand' too, so that may have mattered. Day of surgery you'll get there to check in (5:15 am, for me!) and they rolled me back about 7:30 or so. I met the doc while I was having my IV inserted and some blood drawn in pre-op. My wife was allowed to stay with me for all this, until I was rolled away. After unsuccessfully trying to convince the young fella rolling me down the hallway to stop neat the elevator so I could make a run for it , I entered the OR and met the doc again as well as the surgical staff----then I woke up in recovery! That was about 3 hours later (my surgery was 'open' rather than robotic, so my understanding is that the procedure is a little faster with an experienced surgeon, thus you're not 'out' as long---everyone's mileage varies!). Then I waited for a room (private room in the new tower at Hopkins. Very peaceful.) I was discharged late the next afternoon/early evening (around 4:00 pm I think). For most, it's a one night hospital stay. You can go home after release, though you'll need a driver. You'll have your 'dancing partner' with you, AKA, the catheter, for about 10 days total. I was given the option of removing it myself (Um, no!) but I'm not too far from the hospital so they can do it! Apparently since many folks come to JH from all over, it's an option for some. Doc said he'd send me home with a syringe for the saline. If you decided on a hotel room, you'd likely only need it the night before surgery. Or not at all, if you'd be willing to leave very early the morning of surgery. You'll have to have a 'pre-surgery' visit to get cleared by the anesthesiology department shortly prior to surgery. This took about 1.5-2 hours. You'll also have to have a 'pre-op' visit with your primary care doc to fill out the paperwork for that. My understanding is hospitals used to admit you a day early for that pre-check stuff, but insurance companies got involved, so no more! A Google for 'Johns Hopkins Accommodations' revealed info on hotel discounts near the hospital. Disclaimer: This was my experience specifically related to JH, not everyone's was the same obviously. Good luck! Ron

Posts.Title: Another new club member

Posts.Content: Hi Mj. I admire your 'just get it over with' frame of mind. A Gleason 6 isn't considered an aggressive cancer, so waiting shouldn't cause any physical risks. I was a bit more of the opposite. When I got my Dx back in March '15, I asked my doc how long I could wait?! He said I was at a low risk, but I may want to look inside a 6 month window. I lasted about a month after that appointment before my wife finally got aggravated with me about putting off making the surgery date and finally forced my hand! I still didn't have the surgery until August, but that was nearly 5 months I waited--and everything seems to have turned out well, surgically-wise. Good luck! PS. Can you provide your location?

Posts.Title: Another new club member

Posts.Content: Steve---your prostate size, just my guess, was probably 80 "cc" in volume. As an example, after my MRI, my tests showed my prostate "measures 4.9 cm TV x 3.9 cm AP x 4.7 cm CC, volume 45 CC. Prostate volume calculated in DynaCAD Prostate Boundary 45 mL"--and the doc said mine was a bit enlarged! And of course, just your enlarged prostate will cause your PSA to rise. You can check my sig line to see my numbers, and how things eventually turned out... And you're right about not really knowing how to proceed until you get the results. No point in worrying too much, though we tend to do. You may want to ask your Uro about the PSA3 test and the PSI test, also. Assuming you haven't already. Good luck. Check back in after you get your results. Also, your location may be helpful. Ron

Posts.Title: Another new club member

Posts.Content: SC, from what I've read, PC has been determined to be as much 'sporadic' as it is 'genetic.' Frankly, lots of guys are going to get it, no matter their family history. You just seem to have 'lucked out' like I did. A '1st degree' relative with PC, which your 2nd cousin wasn't on the degree scale, may make one more likely to develop it, but there are boatloads of instances where it didn't make any difference. In my case, my '1st degree' relatives would be my father (nothing yet!), grandfather (died of other issues, so who knows?), a great-grandfather (he had it in the 1960s, but died of other causes), and a brother that died @23 that we'll never know of. To my knowledge we are the only two in the entire family of men to have it! Roughly 18 men sons, grandsons and great-grandson of my grandfather and his siblings. 5 or 6 of them have already passed...only two from cancer...one of those were at my level in the family tree. Kind of speaks volumes right there regarding the sporadic nature of this disease, doesn't it? On a side note, my doc mentioned a possible connection between the PC and Breast Cancer genes. I have to worry here for my daughter, as I've had PC, and my wife's mother passed from BC. Glad you're doing well, Ron

Posts.Title: My Hereditary Connection To PC

Posts.Content: I attended a "Prostate Surgery Pre-Surgical Workshop" today that was actually their inaugural session. It seems they are planning to do these once a month for soon-to-be surgery patients at the hospital. I encourage anyone scheduling surgery at JH to go, and my understanding is that they are matching the upcoming surgeries with patients in order to invite patients to attend. Good slide show and a good question/answer session afterwards with a Urology Nurse Practitioner. It's also interesting to discuss our various situations among ourselves. As the build-up of anxiety until surgery starts, with no professionals to talk to, it was nice to get a chance to ask things that were on all of our minds. We went from pre-procedure, what to bring at admittance, catheter care/handling, incontinence, as well as ED issues--even penis shortening, LOL!. I hope more facilities will implement this type of program. Ron

Posts.Title: If anyone else will be using Johns Hopkins, something new to know

Posts.Content: Hi Fx. Just my 2 cents, but with all those cores, I'm not so sure sending your slides out for a 2nd look is really a necessary expense. Even if JH downgraded (which is unlikely) you to all cores at 3+3=6, you still have an awful lot of positive cores and some with quite high volume involvement. You appear to be going to have to have some type of treatment no matter what. As far as post-surgical radiation, I would think that discussion (at least formally) would wait until after your surgery and your surgical pathology are completed (though your doc may certainly mention the possibility for the future). As far as 'type' of surgery, don't fret the method so much as having an experienced doc. I had 'open' and did just fine. I had minimal blood loss and didn't need a transfusion or any special considerations. Good luck on Friday. Ron

Posts.Title: Biopsy Results in, now what?

Posts.Content: I couldn't decide on a 'Feel the Bern' joke or a 'Weekend at Bernie's' joke, so I'll let it be...... Seriously though, this is all kind of a bummer at 49, right? It was for me at 51. That said, you have plenty of time to decide what to do. One core of G6 isn't gonna kill you anytime in the foreseeable future--if ever. You would seem to be an ideal candidate for Active Surveillance (though some programs discourage this due to your 'young' age) if you want to do that. You can always send your slides off to Dr. Epstein at Hopkins for a second opinion and to get the family off your back, lol! Curious about your history. High PSAs? I don't think you really need to really worry about 'what's in store' for you anytime soon. I had 2 cores of G6 bi-laterally and my doc gave me 6 months of 'thinking time.' You'll get plenty of more responses soon, but I just wanted to welcome you to our little corner of the world. Ron

Posts.Content: Hi wife. Do you actually have the full path report in hand? It would be helpful if you could post it. Obviously we're not doctors though. The 'upgrade' to a G7 is fairly common, and another case of 'you really don't know what you've got until it's under the 'scope' but better a 3/4 than a 4/3. I believe the radiation to be a preventative measure when the margins are positive. Don't get too worried over this as the radiation is a means to ensure that no cancer cells escaped. This JH article may shed some light: http://urology.jhu.edu/newsletter/pr..._cancer410.php And congrats on the <.01! That's always good news!!!

Posts.Title: Back again....questions about pathology

Posts.Content: "...it may have always been there." Unfortunately, so goes biopsies all too often. And your case just shows once again that we really don't know what we have until it's out and under the 'scope. My understanding is that your Gleason is born with what you have. So, if that's the case a G6 doesn't 'jump' to a G7 or higher, but had already been 'born' and was just waiting to be discovered. Sorry about that, but you had good news on the -SV/-LN. I can't advise on your next steps, either, but I can certainly wish you the best! FWIW, my path results were uploaded to my 'patient portal' the day before I spoke to my doc. I didn't look at them before I spoke to him, as I didn't want to misinterpret anything and get too worked up over it. Not sure if you have signed up for that at JH, but if you have, the results may already, or soon will be, uploaded. Good luck to you. Ron

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: Hi Steve. My stepfather was G8 and all I can tell you for sure is that it had 'escaped' after post surgery pathology and it was all through his spine when he died. I don't know much more because he didn't get great treatment in a somewhat rural area and he didn't know much about the disease himself. He battled it for about 6 years, going through all the standard treatments, from surgery to radiation to hormone treatment. I was told that the cancer has spread to my lymph nodes which is what's causing the swelling. Just curious, and maybe I missed it in a previous post, but what is this statement based on? Have you had imaging done, or is this a diagnosis based on something else? Best wishes, Ron

Posts.Title: Life expectancy for advanced prostate cancer in an 81 year old man with an 8 Gl score

Posts.Content: Fred, my initial biopsy was negative. My PCA was 38, which I believed my then-uro stated meant a 57%-77% chance cancer would be found on biopsy--yet it wasn't. When I went to Hopkins, the doctor ordered another blood test, including the "PHI" test. My PSA at that visit was 5.8, my Free PSA was 17.4%, which indicates "only" a 20% probability of cancer, and my PHI was 28.4, which indicates the following, from my "patient portal": In men with total PSA concentrations between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL and a non-suspicious digital rectal examination, phi may be used as an aid in distinguishing prostate cancer from benign conditions. phi Score Probability of Cancer 0-26.9 9.8% 27.0-35.9 16.8% 36.0-54.9 33.3% >54.9 50.1% The clinical utility of phi for total PSA concentrations outside the 4-10 ng/mL range has not been firmly established. For interpretation or questions, consult the following reference: Catalona WL, Partin AW, et al J Urol 2011;185:1650-5. UROLOGY So,while the "numbers" were working in my favor, relatively speaking, it took the 3T MRI to find the "suspicious/indeterminate" area which later was found to be "SMALL FOCUS OF PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA." So, my recommendation? Push for the MRI. Especially the 3T if available. It's painless (though a bit noisy in there!) and the doc can use the images for a "fusion" biopsy if needed.

Posts.Title: Life expectancy for advanced prostate cancer in an 81 year old man with an 8 Gl score

Posts.Content: You've already gotten good advice, PCW, but I don't see anything to be alarmed about in your post (though how your husband escaped is interesting. My wife had to wheel me in a wheelchair to the garage before I could escape!) *Retesting PSA--I've seen guys here get it done at 6 weeks. My doc told me 2-3 months. I'm going to stretch it closer to 3. *Staples--Can you clarify that this was 'robotic' vs. 'open' surgery via the lower abdomen, as I had? I wasn't aware of staples with robotic, but not sure. However, my staples were scheduled to be removed at catheter removal 9 days post-op, but I had an infection or inflammation at my incision site. A nurse was removing my catheter when she noticed this. I wasn't sure what was going on, other than the area was very red and a bit tender to the touch. My surgeon happened to be on the floor, so he took a look, prescribed me a hefty antibiotic to take for a couple of days, and then come back for the staples. He told me at the time that the inflammation may be a reaction of my skin with the metal staples. When I went back, they were removed. A bit tender when the nurse was pressing down on the inflamed skin to clip the staples, but they had to come out. She applied steri-strips to the incision. I probably didn't really need them, as I was healing nicely, but what the heck. They start falling off after a few days, and it's OK. 2 weeks seems a bit longer than most for an uneventful surgery, but it's not unheard of. *Blood in urine is normal and should clear up. Mine was a gross greenish-yellow at times, too, early on. I was told this was the anesthesia remnants clearing out. Blood at tip is normal, too, especially when straining. I had to re-tape my catheter tubing to my leg after a shower. I actually took a pic of the location where it was beforehand--just in case! I felt that supporting the tube as I sat on the toilet helped to keep it from 'pulling' too much. *Meds--I think I took oxys for a day or two when I got home, and then it was just ibuprofen when needed after that. I didn't have much pain, other than the tenderness and the fact that my bottoms just so happen to rub against the incision site. Due to its location, it's kind of hard to avoid. *Any other tips.....Tell him not to get too close to cabinet knobs when in the bathroom. Ya don't wan't to unexpectedly catch that tube on something! Can you advise as to your location?

Posts.Title: Recent Bioipsy Results

Posts.Content: You'll be fine. I found the numbing gel made for a much better 2nd biopsy. I didn't get that during the first. You'll lay on your side, get the gel, then the 'probe' for an initial ultrasound. The doc will do some basics, like measuring your prostate and looking for anything suspicious. Then the numbing needle, followed by the biopsy needles. 12 samples is pretty much standard. You won't really be able to see what the doc's doing (not that you want to!), but you'll hear a 'snap' as the gun shoots off and maybe a little pinch-if that. It won't take long at all. Afterwards, I was told to sit in a small area until I could urinate in a cup. I believe they were checking for clots and anything unusual. You'll have some blood-tinged urine for a few days and likely some dried blood and small clots, as well as, frankly, gross semen! Think tar! But it'll go away soon enough. I found that the more you have a reason to ejaculate, the faster it clears up (don't judge me! ). You'll be fine to drive yourself since only a local is used. I had no pain afterwards. Heck, I hardly even had any blood from the tush--both times! Your doc seemed like a bit of a downer, but I'm sure he was just wishing he could've ruled out PC completely and no biopsy would be necessary. Even HE doesn't know what's going on at this point. P.S., I'm a believer in having a 3T MRI prior to biopsy if possible. It can help identify 'suspicious' areas and allow for a MRI-guided 'fusion biopsy.' Not all docs are onboard with this protocol as of yet though. P.S.S., When buying products like Fleet enemas, do what I do when I have to buy feminine products.....First, use a grocery store and not a local drug store. Be sure to buy lots of unnecessary things to mask what you have, and use SELF CHECKOUT!!! P.S.S.S., Can you advise if you have a family history of PC (you're on the young side for this), and your location?

Posts.Content: Prato, you just pop in every so often with your PSA conundrums to make my head clog up, don't you?! As you know, other than your PNI, our final numbers are very similar. When I had my last (first with my primary care doc) PSA with the whole '0.00' thing, rather than the regular test method that I was used to, I wasn't sure I liked it. As we are both considered 'low risk' (mostly) cases, have you considered asking for, if possible, or seeking out if not, a standard PSA test this time (I have thought about it for my next test)? Did your doc want the uPSA for some reason? I wonder if, on the standard test, you'd get that <.1 number back and eliminate some of your worries (and mine, lol!). If I remember correctly after my surgery, you told me your doc said there's something like a less than 5% chance of a return in your case. Hard to believe you'd fall into that '5%' with your path report. Especially this soon out from surgery. Good luck on Friday. Here's hoing you need to buy some Imodium AD afterwards! Ron

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Welcome, Rob. Sorry you have to be here. My opinion only, but I'm not sure the data available that I've looked at regarding SBRT pertains very well to a man of your young age for the long term. I just haven't found too many young guys being recommended for it, by either surgeons or Rad Oncs. I'd ask about your options at that point if a recurrence happens should you seek that treatment option out. If you have surgery, I wouldn't fret the method so much as the doc's experience. I had 'open' and I'm fine over a year and a half later. No large blood loss or anything weird. I didn't even have the 'gas' issues some guys have since I didn't have to be 'inflated' lol! I was just shy of 52 at the time. My erection issues aren't perfect, but I can do the deed. Pills help if needed. And you're younger than me, so probably even better. Did you talk with the doc about sparing nerves? I drip occasionally when I do something stressful, but I'm mostly OK. But as my wife said, "I'd rather have you with a dribble than not have you at all." Unfortunately, quite a few guys get upgraded from those Gleason 6 scores to something higher (as was I with low numbers on everything pre-surgery). I hope that's not the case with you, but it's an unknown until the pathologist looks at it once it's out. Radiation doesn't afford that, nor does it give you the backup plan that surgery does in case it comes back a few years later. One last thing. Be thankful your doc was on the ball and did the DRE and found something suspicious. Those aren't perfect, but many docs don't perform them on younger guys. Did you have a family history of some kind that required a closer look, or was it just your doc's protocol? Best wishes. Ron

Mine was with Dr. Herbert Ballentine Carter (Call me 'Bal'), director of adult urology with close to 4000 RPs under his belt, just this August 10. He does open via the lower abdomen, and I'm A-OK! Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Yes. Many here have had it. Once I switched to Johns Hopkins it was the first thing the new doc recommended (well that and sticking a Q-tip up my tush, LOL!). The doc I was seeing before the switch (and who performed my first negative biopsy) wanted to proceed with a saturation biopsy as the next step. That's when I decided that there had to be a better way! The 3T found an undetermined 'suspicious' lesion that was targeted during the subsequent fusion biopsy. The MRI can't diagnose cancer, so you'll still need the biopsy, but I felt better knowing the doc wasn't 'shooting blind' during the second one. Only surprise I had was that in addition to the 'targeted' area, they still take the normal 12 samples too. Thus, my second biopsy was 14 needles. Another benefit to the 3T, IMO, is that it gave us a good indication that my lymph nodes and seminal vesicles looked normal, as well as that there didn't appear to be any prostate capsule escape (extraprostatic extension). That gave me at least some relief going into this. Ron

Posts.Title: My Free/Total PSA Results

Posts.Content: Unfortunately, blind 12 core biopsies miss, as my first one did. Not sure, but would a larger prostate due to BPH cause more likelihood of missing cancer? I'll never forget being anxious over awaiting the results and being told by the 'then' doc that it was "good news" and "whatever is affecting my PSA, it wasn't cancer" -- only to have yet another elevated PSA on the next visit and a recommendation for a sat biopsy. Kind of deflating, really..... I'm not saying you have cancer -- hopefully you don't. If it were just your PSA, and not your fPSA also, I may be more inclined to think it's something else affecting your numbers. The 3T, in my case, was able to identify the suspicious area. The 'PIRADS' score of the lesion, which runs on a 1-5 scale on me was a "3" meaning malignancy couldn't be determined. A '5' would've been indicative that cancer was very likely, a '1' very unlikely. Regarding the PCA3 urine test, it indicates the likelihood of cancer being found upon biopsy. So, if it ends up showing that probability, you're going to get the 3T and another biopsy anyways. So, IMO, I'd just go with the 3T in the first place. Ron

I think we've all heard these stories and it did come up at the workshop that I just attended at Hopkins as someone asked the question that he felt was the "elephant in the room" so to speak. The nurse practitioner (specialized in urology) said basically that it doesn't really happen often enough to worry about it and if it does, it isn't really noticeable. It was funny watching my wife's facial reaction when the question was asked though! As the guy asked the question, and the woman was answering it, I just thought to myself: "What other options do we have?" Maybe a couple of millimeters knocked off the 'little guy' or metastasized cancer in our bodies?

Posts.Title: An Essay on Penis Shortening.

Posts.Content: Hi Flags and welcome. A bit off topic to start, but my step-father was Vietnam era navy, mainly carriers, as an 'Aviation Electrician's Mate.' Retired as a an E-6 in '77 after doing 20 years. He says that he, too, had Agent Orange exposure, though being considered 'blue water' navy, it would've been a fight to get benefits and he didn't pursue them. No family history, so who knows if the AO was a contributor. Unfortunately, he could've received better care, both in his home state of Maryland, and after relocating to North Carolina. He was diagnosed at age 70 with PC and underwent surgery. At pathology, he was Gleason 8 and it was outside the capsule. He fought a tough 6 year battle with every available treatment, with many ups and downs, but he finally lost the battle just over a year ago at 77. I'm glad to see you are staying on top of your situation and wish you well. Hopefully, everything is contained. And who knows? A signalman is a carrier guy too, right? Maybe you guys even crossed paths at some point. And of course, thanks for your service! Ron

Posts.Content: I bet this is no time to be modest. I bet my little guy will be on full display for all to see. Just not comfortable with this happening. Yeah, bro, forget your modesty. I didn't have the scan you mentioned prior to catheter removal, but if it helps you relax any, they put the catheter in after they knock you out for surgery. So, at least you don't know to be embarrassed! My wife was like "really? Have you ever had a OBGYN exam?" Well, of course not, silly! I had, however, gone through a (wasted as it turned out) vasectomy about a year before my surgery, and the two cute assisting nurses didn't exactly help on the embarrassment front! Neither did it help when the young cutie pulled my catheter afterwards, but remember; a urologic nurse has seen a thousand of those things! Ron
