Posts.Content: Anyone have experience going out of network with their insurance? It's all a PITA, but what's your specific question about going 'out of network?' My very experienced surgeon didn't take one of the most popular providers in the country (Carefirst BC/BS), which amazed me. If out of network, you may have a co-insurance penalty to pay, but there are also usually out of pocket maximums per year. I (meaning my wife, lol) decided it was worth going out of network in my case. Good luck with your surgery! Ron

Posts.Title: Ouch!

Posts.Content: ...should i still request the 3T MRI? I don't see how the MRI could hurt. I still have a hard time believing you have PC at your age, but it does happen. The 3T can locate a lesion, which may/may not be cancerous, and also provide a glimpse of your SVs and LNs, as well as the prostate capsule itself. And as Michael said, those images can then be used to perform a 'fusion biopsy' if there's anything suspicious. Because of your PSA level, you may very well end up having a biopsy anyways. Limiting the number of biopsies you have is always a good thing, and the MRI guided route is certainly preferable, as blind biopsies often miss the target. And who wants to go through with that again?! Good Luck. Ron

Posts.Title: About to make the decision

Posts.Content: j....it's always good to have leave. As retired LE now, I'd have to tell my rookies (FTO) that while I realize you're young, and the shifts and days off suck, there's gonna be a time when you want that leave...babies, off duty injuries, illness, etc. I tore my rotator cuff in '12 shoveling snow at home with about 2.5 years to retirement. I thought about the whole 'light duty' thing, but with an 80 mile round trip drive and 6 months of sick leave, I said screw it--- I'm staying home!!! It was nearly 4 months... I'm an example...... Surgery was 1/20/12 at that! BTW, be sure to utilize your department's FMLA procedures if you're gonna have anything that could affect you by taking off/burning leave. They can't hold it against you, legally, though it's a bit of a hassle sometimes to facilitate. And I agree with your doc. Even after taking the time off that I did, I couldn't help but subconsciously wonder if I might suffer a re-tear in an altercation. And that was just my shoulder, not my plumbing, LOL! Ron

Posts.Title: When to go back to work

Posts.Content: Can't help you with the doc request, I'm sure you'll get several recommendations. Just wanted to say give a big welcome our club, which unfortunately no one wants to be a member of. Which part of Missouri? Sometimes it worth going out of state for treatment, especially if you're close to the state line. You can place that in your profile if you'd like. 46 is indeed on the young side, but as we all know, it happens. Do you have a family history of PCa? I ask because most screenings don't tend to begin until 50 (not wise, IMHO) unless there's a higher risk or some type of symptoms. If you are able to get your report, I'd recommend you update your signature with the results. That way we don't have to keep bugging you about stuff! Your doc's point makes perfect sense. I'd say this site tends to lean towards surgery over other treatments, especially in younger guys, so if that's the route you're set to take, you'll get plenty of support and advice here. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Second PSA-test after surgery..

Posts.Content: Hi jks. As already noted by Southsider's and MM's posts, you're awfully young to have PCa. I'd also believe another cause is elevating your PSA, such as an infection. By any chance soon before your PSA tests, did you do any activities that could elevate your PSA numbers? For instance, have sex within a couple days before the tests? Ride a bike for an extended time? These are thought to artificially inflate your PSA and it's normally recommended that one refrain from such activities before the test. How about the DRE? Was it performed before or after (hopefully) your blood draw? That, or any other stimulus to your prostate gland could give an artificial reading. What was your initial PSA number from your first doctor? That said, a MRI is painless though with your PSA of 2.5, even in the unlikely event you did have PCa, it's possible the tumor would be too small to show up. I give your doc some credit though. At least he's suggesting a MRI before trying to line you up for a biopsy. Most men don't get that offer first! Where are you located? You can include that info in your profile. God luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: The blood test was done after the DRE For the life of me, I don't understand how medically trained doctors, especially uros, continue to do this. You could consider asking about a retest ASAP since you have concerns about its accuracy due to the DRE, or, you could just wait it out until your next visit---keeping in mind to abstain from any activities and keep the doc away from your rear end until AFTER the blood is drawn! Jeesh! Let us know when you get your initial PSA back. At least that one was probably 'DRE free!'

Posts.Title: New to forum, need help

Posts.Content: Hi jks. As already noted by Southsider's and MM's posts, you're awfully young to have PCa. I'd also believe another cause is elevating your PSA, such as an infection. By any chance soon before your PSA tests, did you do any activities that could elevate your PSA numbers? For instance, have sex within a couple days before the tests? Ride a bike for an extended time? These are thought to artificially inflate your PSA and it's normally recommended that one refrain from such activities before the test. How about the DRE? Was it performed before or after (hopefully) your blood draw? That, or any other stimulus to your prostate gland could give an artificial reading. What was your initial PSA number from your first doctor? That said, a MRI is painless though with your PSA of 2.5, even in the unlikely event you did have PCa, it's possible the tumor would be too small to show up. I give your doc some credit though. At least he's suggesting a MRI before trying to line you up for a biopsy. Most men don't get that offer first! Where are you located? You can include that info in your profile. God luck. Ron

Posts.Content: Hi Jeremy. Sounds very much like when I tore my rotator cuff 5 years ago. It can happen over time with normal wear and tear, especially if your occupation caused lots of demand on the joint, or it could happen suddenly--like being a big dummy and slipping and falling while shoveling snow (guess who?!). I began getting these shooting pains down the outside of my arm, from about the shoulder to the elbow, after certain movements. Later, it became difficult to raise my coffee mug--that's when it got serious! An x-ray did me no good, but I was eventually sent for a MRI which showed the tear. You may want to consider seeing an orthopedist. You may just need physical therapy to loosen things up again. Good luck, Ron

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: Man, Wayne. That's a tough one. Any way you could go to the doc without your wife?! I'm on the somewhat opposite end of the spectrum--I'm procrastinating over surgery, and my wife is pestering the crap out of me about scheduling it! Are your 4 cores uni or bi-lateral (on 1 or both sides of the prostate)? Some AS programs take this into consideration. While I'm not a particularly religious man, I've generally held the belief that God helps those that help themselves. I'd say if you're a "believer" then those people in the clean white coats, as well as all of that fancy equipment, are a product of God and are here at His will to help us--and you! Kind of like the joke: There was a preacher who fell in the ocean and he couldn't swim. When a boat came by, the captain yelled, "Do you need help, sir?" The preacher calmly said "No, God will save me." A little later, another boat came by and a fisherman asked, "Hey, do you need help?" The preacher replied again, "No God will save me." Eventually the preacher drowned & went to heaven. The preacher asked God, "Why didn't you save me?" God replied, "Fool, I sent you two boats!" I'm not going to criticize another guy's wife, but her line of thinking, frankly, astounds me. I just watched my stepfather die of this disease after a 6 year battle. It wasn't pretty. I had an aunt with breast cancer that refused most medical treatment and relied on"holistic" methods. She didn't make it past 49 years old. Personally, I think you have to get some kind of treatment, whether surgery or radiation. Also personally, I don't think that I can live comfortably knowing it's still inside of me, so I'm likely going the surgery route. Good luck, man.

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. Michael: Not sure about that mirror, but I don't have quite the same anxiety as I used to have. Rob: You're reading it right. It might be more accurate to credit my wife's persistence, lol. Boy, what a PITA! But.....she knows I procrastinate. It was at her insistence that I departed my local uro group and headed up to JH. Djin: Thanks. I know I haven't had the toughest case by any stretch, but this whole thing caught me off-guard. I had almost forgotten it was my 'anniversary' as I guess my wife had. I mentioned it this morning and she cried. Just like she did when Dr. Carter explained to us my path report was a good one. I don't want her to be upset, but after being together for about 25 years, it's a bit reassuring in some aspects. I'll be 55 in a couple of weeks, but it's still good to be on this side of the grass.

Posts.Content: A bucket.....for when he 'goes' lol! Seriously though, I used Depends pads until I found the comparable 'store brand' pads worked just as well. Pharmacies (Rite Aid, Walgreen's, CVS) or grocery stores have them. I bought some adult wipes from the same section of the store. Larger than those wipes in a tube. The main thing is keeping dry and clean. I wouldn't over-worry it. It seems worse than it really is. A pad in my drawers and I never had a leak accident. Eventually I moved up to just Depends shields. I'd definitely have a pad for the ride home from the catheter removal though. You just don't know..... And enjoy cath removal day----I know HE will!!!

Posts.Title: What supplies to get after removing catheter?

Posts.Content: I couldn't decide on a 'Feel the Bern' joke or a 'Weekend at Bernie's' joke, so I'll let it be...... Seriously though, this is all kind of a bummer at 49, right? It was for me at 51. That said, you have plenty of time to decide what to do. One core of G6 isn't gonna kill you anytime in the foreseeable future--if ever. You would seem to be an ideal candidate for Active Surveillance (though some programs discourage this due to your 'young' age) if you want to do that. You can always send your slides off to Dr. Epstein at Hopkins for a second opinion and to get the family off your back, lol! Curious about your history. High PSAs? I don't think you really need to really worry about 'what's in store' for you anytime soon. I had 2 cores of G6 bi-laterally and my doc gave me 6 months of 'thinking time.' You'll get plenty of more responses soon, but I just wanted to welcome you to our little corner of the world. Ron

Posts.Content: I just realized that 3 years ago today I was eating Jello, clear broth, and preparing to shoot stuff up my rectum as I awaited early morning surgery at Johns Hopkins with a 0515 check in. I even wondered if my doc would be awake! I guess better to be first on the table than last. I suppose it's a good thing when one doesn't constantly worry anymore..... My next PSA will be with my primary doc next month, but so far, so good. Best of luck to those following our paths. Ron

Posts.Title: 3 years.....

Posts.Content: Dave, where are you located? And what do you hope do accomplish by a second opinion? I'm only asking because you have a lot of G6 cores and I also agree that it's a T2C--both lobes. As that whole 'bilateral' issue kept me out of AS, I'd have to assume there are concerns with that. IMO, with all of those positive cores, you're going to need treatment. I agree with your uro, but the question is which treatment is best for you at 63? Active Surveillance is out, and if you're thinking RP or radiation, will that 2nd opinion change anything? Good luck to you, Ron

Posts.Title: Reluctant new member questions, including second opinion on biopsy and stage of PC

Posts.Content: Fred, my initial biopsy was negative. My PCA was 38, which I believed my then-uro stated meant a 57%-77% chance cancer would be found on biopsy--yet it wasn't. When I went to Hopkins, the doctor ordered another blood test, including the "PHI" test. My PSA at that visit was 5.8, my Free PSA was 17.4%, which indicates "only" a 20% probability of cancer, and my PHI was 28.4, which indicates the following, from my "patient portal": In men with total PSA concentrations between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL and a non-suspicious digital rectal examination, phi may be used as an aid in distinguishing prostate cancer from benign conditions. phi Score Probability of Cancer 0-26.9 9.8% 27.0-35.9 16.8% 36.0-54.9 33.3% >54.9 50.1% The clinical utility of phi for total PSA concentrations outside the 4-10 ng/mL range has not been firmly established. For interpretation or questions, consult the following reference: Catalona WL, Partin AW, et al J Urol 2011;185:1650-5. UROLOGY So,while the "numbers" were working in my favor, relatively speaking, it took the 3T MRI to find the "suspicious/indeterminate" area which later was found to be "SMALL FOCUS OF PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA." So, my recommendation? Push for the MRI. Especially the 3T if available. It's painless (though a bit noisy in there!) and the doc can use the images for a "fusion" biopsy if needed.

Posts.Title: What have been your experiences with new PHI test

Posts.Content: Welcome Geezer--unfortunately you're inquiring with us. I believe the 'DCE' refers to using contrast (Dynamic contrast-enhancement) with the MRI. Did you mean 'extraprostatic extension?' If so, unfortunately, that means evidence was seen on the images that the tumor is beyond the confines of the gland into the surrounding tissue (periprostatic tissue). Please don't freak yourself out though!!! Let's get the biopsy over with and then you and your docs can decide on a plan of action. The only definitive way for a diagnoses of cancer is a biopsy. You don't have that yet, you merely have unidentified 'lesions' at this point. Additionally, can you provide your location? Maybe put it in your profile? Good luck to you, sir! Ron

Posts.Title: Suspect MRI, awaiting Biopsy

Posts.Content: Prato, you just pop in every so often with your PSA conundrums to make my head clog up, don't you?! As you know, other than your PNI, our final numbers are very similar. When I had my last (first with my primary care doc) PSA with the whole '0.00' thing, rather than the regular test method that I was used to, I wasn't sure I liked it. As we are both considered 'low risk' (mostly) cases, have you considered asking for, if possible, or seeking out if not, a standard PSA test this time (I have thought about it for my next test)? Did your doc want the uPSA for some reason? I wonder if, on the standard test, you'd get that <.1 number back and eliminate some of your worries (and mine, lol!). If I remember correctly after my surgery, you told me your doc said there's something like a less than 5% chance of a return in your case. Hard to believe you'd fall into that '5%' with your path report. Especially this soon out from surgery. Good luck on Friday. Here's hoing you need to buy some Imodium AD afterwards! Ron

Posts.Title: Viagra battle about to start

Posts.Content: Lil, just to clarify, did you actually receive a bill for $2500 from the doc, or was that charge submitted to BCBC and they denied it for some reason or other, like an 'incidental' charge and you see it on your Explanation of Benefits (EOB)? I think that code refers to robotic assisted surgery, but it's considered incidental to the surgery charge, as in 'the doc is getting paid for surgery, how he does it is up to him.' Found this: Robotic Surgical Systems: Surgical techniques requiring use of robotics surgical system (S2900) will be considered incidental to surgical services. Payment for new technology is based on the outcome of the treatment rather than the “technology” involved in the procedure. Separate reimbursement is not allowed for the robotic surgical technique. I remember my doc bill, anesthesia bill, and basic hospital charges/room bill were separate, but there was no charge for any second surgeon.

Posts.Title: Swollen penis six days after surgery

Posts.Content: You'll be fine. I found the numbing gel made for a much better 2nd biopsy. I didn't get that during the first. You'll lay on your side, get the gel, then the 'probe' for an initial ultrasound. The doc will do some basics, like measuring your prostate and looking for anything suspicious. Then the numbing needle, followed by the biopsy needles. 12 samples is pretty much standard. You won't really be able to see what the doc's doing (not that you want to!), but you'll hear a 'snap' as the gun shoots off and maybe a little pinch-if that. It won't take long at all. Afterwards, I was told to sit in a small area until I could urinate in a cup. I believe they were checking for clots and anything unusual. You'll have some blood-tinged urine for a few days and likely some dried blood and small clots, as well as, frankly, gross semen! Think tar! But it'll go away soon enough. I found that the more you have a reason to ejaculate, the faster it clears up (don't judge me! ). You'll be fine to drive yourself since only a local is used. I had no pain afterwards. Heck, I hardly even had any blood from the tush--both times! Your doc seemed like a bit of a downer, but I'm sure he was just wishing he could've ruled out PC completely and no biopsy would be necessary. Even HE doesn't know what's going on at this point. P.S., I'm a believer in having a 3T MRI prior to biopsy if possible. It can help identify 'suspicious' areas and allow for a MRI-guided 'fusion biopsy.' Not all docs are onboard with this protocol as of yet though. P.S.S., When buying products like Fleet enemas, do what I do when I have to buy feminine products.....First, use a grocery store and not a local drug store. Be sure to buy lots of unnecessary things to mask what you have, and use SELF CHECKOUT!!! P.S.S.S., Can you advise if you have a family history of PC (you're on the young side for this), and your location?

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Yes. Many here have had it. Once I switched to Johns Hopkins it was the first thing the new doc recommended (well that and sticking a Q-tip up my tush, LOL!). The doc I was seeing before the switch (and who performed my first negative biopsy) wanted to proceed with a saturation biopsy as the next step. That's when I decided that there had to be a better way! The 3T found an undetermined 'suspicious' lesion that was targeted during the subsequent fusion biopsy. The MRI can't diagnose cancer, so you'll still need the biopsy, but I felt better knowing the doc wasn't 'shooting blind' during the second one. Only surprise I had was that in addition to the 'targeted' area, they still take the normal 12 samples too. Thus, my second biopsy was 14 needles. Another benefit to the 3T, IMO, is that it gave us a good indication that my lymph nodes and seminal vesicles looked normal, as well as that there didn't appear to be any prostate capsule escape (extraprostatic extension). That gave me at least some relief going into this. Ron

Posts.Content: Time flies.... I'll leave the reference to "fun" out though! I guess if you're fortunate enough to nearly forget, it's not a bad thing to do so necessarily. I haven't updated my PSAs to date. I'm not really crazy that, since I went ahead and just decided to let my primary care doc run the test along with my usual blood work every 6 month for the convenience, a different assay is used. The last 2 have been .02, but it's not the standard test that JH was doing. I figure '.02' is still '<.1'. If the one next month is any different I may call Dr. Carter's assistant and ask for a blood draw up there to, hopefully, see my '<' again. Other than that, I feel pretty good. I get an occasional stress squirt, but I blame myself, as well as coffee, and Captain Morgan and his raiding party. On the ED front, it's workable. I'm not in my 20s anymore, so I accept that things are different. Best wishes to all.... Ron

Posts.Title: Hey! I just realized that today was my two year surgery anniversary!

Posts.Content: Welcome, Rob. Sorry you have to be here. My opinion only, but I'm not sure the data available that I've looked at regarding SBRT pertains very well to a man of your young age for the long term. I just haven't found too many young guys being recommended for it, by either surgeons or Rad Oncs. I'd ask about your options at that point if a recurrence happens should you seek that treatment option out. If you have surgery, I wouldn't fret the method so much as the doc's experience. I had 'open' and I'm fine over a year and a half later. No large blood loss or anything weird. I didn't even have the 'gas' issues some guys have since I didn't have to be 'inflated' lol! I was just shy of 52 at the time. My erection issues aren't perfect, but I can do the deed. Pills help if needed. And you're younger than me, so probably even better. Did you talk with the doc about sparing nerves? I drip occasionally when I do something stressful, but I'm mostly OK. But as my wife said, "I'd rather have you with a dribble than not have you at all." Unfortunately, quite a few guys get upgraded from those Gleason 6 scores to something higher (as was I with low numbers on everything pre-surgery). I hope that's not the case with you, but it's an unknown until the pathologist looks at it once it's out. Radiation doesn't afford that, nor does it give you the backup plan that surgery does in case it comes back a few years later. One last thing. Be thankful your doc was on the ball and did the DRE and found something suspicious. Those aren't perfect, but many docs don't perform them on younger guys. Did you have a family history of some kind that required a closer look, or was it just your doc's protocol? Best wishes. Ron

Posts.Title: Struggling with course of treatment decision?

Posts.Content: I couldn't decide on a 'Feel the Bern' joke or a 'Weekend at Bernie's' joke, so I'll let it be...... Seriously though, this is all kind of a bummer at 49, right? It was for me at 51. That said, you have plenty of time to decide what to do. One core of G6 isn't gonna kill you anytime in the foreseeable future--if ever. You would seem to be an ideal candidate for Active Surveillance (though some programs discourage this due to your 'young' age) if you want to do that. You can always send your slides off to Dr. Epstein at Hopkins for a second opinion and to get the family off your back, lol! Curious about your history. High PSAs? I don't think you really need to really worry about 'what's in store' for you anytime soon. I had 2 cores of G6 bi-laterally and my doc gave me 6 months of 'thinking time.' You'll get plenty of more responses soon, but I just wanted to welcome you to our little corner of the world. Ron

Posts.Title: New Diagnosis

Posts.Content: Fred, my initial biopsy was negative. My PCA was 38, which I believed my then-uro stated meant a 57%-77% chance cancer would be found on biopsy--yet it wasn't. When I went to Hopkins, the doctor ordered another blood test, including the "PHI" test. My PSA at that visit was 5.8, my Free PSA was 17.4%, which indicates "only" a 20% probability of cancer, and my PHI was 28.4, which indicates the following, from my "patient portal": In men with total PSA concentrations between 4.0 and 10.0 ng/mL and a non-suspicious digital rectal examination, phi may be used as an aid in distinguishing prostate cancer from benign conditions. phi Score Probability of Cancer 0-26.9 9.8% 27.0-35.9 16.8% 36.0-54.9 33.3% >54.9 50.1% The clinical utility of phi for total PSA concentrations outside the 4-10 ng/mL range has not been firmly established. For interpretation or questions, consult the following reference: Catalona WL, Partin AW, et al J Urol 2011;185:1650-5. UROLOGY So,while the "numbers" were working in my favor, relatively speaking, it took the 3T MRI to find the "suspicious/indeterminate" area which later was found to be "SMALL FOCUS OF PROSTATIC ADENOCARCINOMA." So, my recommendation? Push for the MRI. Especially the 3T if available. It's painless (though a bit noisy in there!) and the doc can use the images for a "fusion" biopsy if needed.

Posts.Title: What have been your experiences with new PHI test

Posts.Content: You've already gotten good advice, PCW, but I don't see anything to be alarmed about in your post (though how your husband escaped is interesting. My wife had to wheel me in a wheelchair to the garage before I could escape!) *Retesting PSA--I've seen guys here get it done at 6 weeks. My doc told me 2-3 months. I'm going to stretch it closer to 3. *Staples--Can you clarify that this was 'robotic' vs. 'open' surgery via the lower abdomen, as I had? I wasn't aware of staples with robotic, but not sure. However, my staples were scheduled to be removed at catheter removal 9 days post-op, but I had an infection or inflammation at my incision site. A nurse was removing my catheter when she noticed this. I wasn't sure what was going on, other than the area was very red and a bit tender to the touch. My surgeon happened to be on the floor, so he took a look, prescribed me a hefty antibiotic to take for a couple of days, and then come back for the staples. He told me at the time that the inflammation may be a reaction of my skin with the metal staples. When I went back, they were removed. A bit tender when the nurse was pressing down on the inflamed skin to clip the staples, but they had to come out. She applied steri-strips to the incision. I probably didn't really need them, as I was healing nicely, but what the heck. They start falling off after a few days, and it's OK. 2 weeks seems a bit longer than most for an uneventful surgery, but it's not unheard of. *Blood in urine is normal and should clear up. Mine was a gross greenish-yellow at times, too, early on. I was told this was the anesthesia remnants clearing out. Blood at tip is normal, too, especially when straining. I had to re-tape my catheter tubing to my leg after a shower. I actually took a pic of the location where it was beforehand--just in case! I felt that supporting the tube as I sat on the toilet helped to keep it from 'pulling' too much. *Meds--I think I took oxys for a day or two when I got home, and then it was just ibuprofen when needed after that. I didn't have much pain, other than the tenderness and the fact that my bottoms just so happen to rub against the incision site. Due to its location, it's kind of hard to avoid. *Any other tips.....Tell him not to get too close to cabinet knobs when in the bathroom. Ya don't wan't to unexpectedly catch that tube on something! Can you advise as to your location?

Posts.Content: Regarding the Kegels, my instruction sheet from JH states 'Although there is no standard method to performing Kegals......' It goes on to suggest 3 sets of 15 reps each, and that one set be performed while standing, one set while sitting, and one set while lying down--the reasoning being those are the 3 positions one is most likely to find himself in during everyday life when he has to consciously hold urine, i.e., 'go!'

Posts.Content: Was there any defining moments where you just thought, "wow, this woman has my back"? Mine was a PITA at times over this, but she knows I procrastinate, especially over things I don't really want to to. Really? What guy wants to do this??!! We'd been married over 20 years at the time of surgery, together almost 22 years. She had ZERO confidence in my initial urology group, especially after my initial negative biopsy, and 'phoned a friend' to get me a reference to a doc at Johns Hopkins. When I got my good post-op path report she broke down crying..... She was obviously more freaked out than I was. I didn't want to see her upset, but I appreciated the concern. She's still a PITA though, but not a member of this forum, LOL!

Posts.Title: One Year Anniversary

Posts.Content: Lil, just to clarify, did you actually receive a bill for $2500 from the doc, or was that charge submitted to BCBC and they denied it for some reason or other, like an 'incidental' charge and you see it on your Explanation of Benefits (EOB)? I think that code refers to robotic assisted surgery, but it's considered incidental to the surgery charge, as in 'the doc is getting paid for surgery, how he does it is up to him.' Found this: Robotic Surgical Systems: Surgical techniques requiring use of robotics surgical system (S2900) will be considered incidental to surgical services. Payment for new technology is based on the outcome of the treatment rather than the “technology” involved in the procedure. Separate reimbursement is not allowed for the robotic surgical technique. I remember my doc bill, anesthesia bill, and basic hospital charges/room bill were separate, but there was no charge for any second surgeon.

Posts.Content: Prato, you just pop in every so often with your PSA conundrums to make my head clog up, don't you?! As you know, other than your PNI, our final numbers are very similar. When I had my last (first with my primary care doc) PSA with the whole '0.00' thing, rather than the regular test method that I was used to, I wasn't sure I liked it. As we are both considered 'low risk' (mostly) cases, have you considered asking for, if possible, or seeking out if not, a standard PSA test this time (I have thought about it for my next test)? Did your doc want the uPSA for some reason? I wonder if, on the standard test, you'd get that <.1 number back and eliminate some of your worries (and mine, lol!). If I remember correctly after my surgery, you told me your doc said there's something like a less than 5% chance of a return in your case. Hard to believe you'd fall into that '5%' with your path report. Especially this soon out from surgery. Good luck on Friday. Here's hoing you need to buy some Imodium AD afterwards! Ron

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Hi, gppr100rs. I had similar thoughts as you regarding the 24 core "saturation" biopsy. After my initial 12 core TRUS didn't find anything I was hopeful, but as my PSA scores were still high, I knew _something_ had to be going on. My Urologist then recommended the "saturation" biopsy. I kept putting it off because, frankly, I didn't want to do it! I wasn't crazy about the aftermath (bloody urine/semen) of the TRUS, so I certainly didn't think that 24 needles was going to be somehow better! And I had the same concerns also: This is shooting blindly and hoping to hit something. What if this missed, too? What next--a 48 needle biopsy??? Ouch!!! That's when I decided to get a different perspective and go see a Hopkins doctor. The first thing he told me regarding a saturation biopsy was "I wouldn't do that." I thought--whew!!! I proceeded to get a recommended MRI, which showed a "suspicious area." I followed that up with a MRI-guided fusion biopsy, which found the cancer. While I'm not at all happy anything was found, I'm happy it was found this time, and without 24--or more-- needles! I guess I was naive as I thought the second biopsy would only take samples from the suspicious are, but nope! It took samples from that area in addition to the standard 12 core standard TRUS biopsy, so 14 cores this time. Personally, I'd go the "fusion" route. Good luck.

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: Of course. Still a top rated urological facility. Mine was with Dr. Herbert Ballentine Carter (Call me 'Bal'), director of adult urology with close to 4000 RPs under his belt, just this August 10. He does open via the lower abdomen, and I'm A-OK! Still a bit 'dribbly' but no complications. And I think I'm going to make it through the ED phase OK. dshinnick (Dave), another forum poster, had Allaf as his surgeon and appears to be doing fine, and Allaf recommended Carter if he preferred the 'open' route. For the most part, I don't think you'd go wrong with any. Dr. Carter had the first available appointment, so I took it. My urologist at the time was suggesting a saturation biopsy after the first one didn't find anything, but Carter sent me for the 3T before another one. I give kudos for that! Come on down, Steve. I'll buy you a crab cake....LOL!

Posts.Content: Regarding the Kegels, my instruction sheet from JH states 'Although there is no standard method to performing Kegals......' It goes on to suggest 3 sets of 15 reps each, and that one set be performed while standing, one set while sitting, and one set while lying down--the reasoning being those are the 3 positions one is most likely to find himself in during everyday life when he has to consciously hold urine, i.e., 'go!'

Which part of Missouri? Sometimes it worth going out of state for treatment, especially if you're close to the state line. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Content: Marve, I don't know about the pathology being bad, but maybe if the doctor isn't going to give you ALL of the information that you need, he should just shut up until he isn't so "busy" and do so when he can talk to you freely! Giving you half the story isn't helpful to YOU! Besides, when you first posted didn't you mention that after the biopsy your doctor was already talking about radiation after surgery? And he didn't even have a pathology report then, so it sounds like, based on what you're telling us, that the doctor already had his mind made up regarding radiation. I don't remember anything from your original post regarding the biopsy results that would suggest that course of treatment--at least in the USA. Hopefully 'Dr. Busy' will come around with more information as well as a written pathology report, but let's hope your meeting with the Radiation Oncologist will answer your questions.

Posts.Content: Doing the DRE *after* the blood draw would force a change in protocol. LOL. Well, we can't have that can we?! I'd never had a DRE before seeing my first urologist and I remember when he eventually mentioned he was going to have me submit to a PSA, and later a PCA3 test, probably because of a similar protocol, told me when I came back in for that to be sure that 1) I didn't urinate before the test--standard to check for infections I guess, and 2) inform the tech that I needed a blood draw before I saw him. However, my regular doc never gave me a DRE. He just did a regular blood draw and included the PSA because I'd just turned 50. When he referred me to a uro, I was drawn before the exam.

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: Hi jks. As already noted by Southsider's and MM's posts, you're awfully young to have PCa. I'd also believe another cause is elevating your PSA, such as an infection. By any chance soon before your PSA tests, did you do any activities that could elevate your PSA numbers? For instance, have sex within a couple days before the tests? Ride a bike for an extended time? These are thought to artificially inflate your PSA and it's normally recommended that one refrain from such activities before the test. How about the DRE? Was it performed before or after (hopefully) your blood draw? That, or any other stimulus to your prostate gland could give an artificial reading. What was your initial PSA number from your first doctor? That said, a MRI is painless though with your PSA of 2.5, even in the unlikely event you did have PCa, it's possible the tumor would be too small to show up. I give your doc some credit though. At least he's suggesting a MRI before trying to line you up for a biopsy. Most men don't get that offer first! Where are you located? You can include that info in your profile. God luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Age 33 - PSA 2.5 NERVOUS!!

Posts.Content: Man, Wayne. That's a tough one. Any way you could go to the doc without your wife?! I'm on the somewhat opposite end of the spectrum--I'm procrastinating over surgery, and my wife is pestering the crap out of me about scheduling it! Are your 4 cores uni or bi-lateral (on 1 or both sides of the prostate)? Some AS programs take this into consideration. While I'm not a particularly religious man, I've generally held the belief that God helps those that help themselves. I'd say if you're a "believer" then those people in the clean white coats, as well as all of that fancy equipment, are a product of God and are here at His will to help us--and you! Kind of like the joke: There was a preacher who fell in the ocean and he couldn't swim. When a boat came by, the captain yelled, "Do you need help, sir?" The preacher calmly said "No, God will save me." A little later, another boat came by and a fisherman asked, "Hey, do you need help?" The preacher replied again, "No God will save me." Eventually the preacher drowned & went to heaven. The preacher asked God, "Why didn't you save me?" God replied, "Fool, I sent you two boats!" I'm not going to criticize another guy's wife, but her line of thinking, frankly, astounds me. I just watched my stepfather die of this disease after a 6 year battle. It wasn't pretty. I had an aunt with breast cancer that refused most medical treatment and relied on"holistic" methods. She didn't make it past 49 years old. Personally, I think you have to get some kind of treatment, whether surgery or radiation. Also personally, I don't think that I can live comfortably knowing it's still inside of me, so I'm likely going the surgery route. Good luck, man.

Posts.Content: Can't help you with the doc request, I'm sure you'll get several recommendations. Just wanted to say give a big welcome our club, which unfortunately no one wants to be a member of. Which part of Missouri? Sometimes it worth going out of state for treatment, especially if you're close to the state line. You can place that in your profile if you'd like. 46 is indeed on the young side, but as we all know, it happens. Do you have a family history of PCa? I ask because most screenings don't tend to begin until 50 (not wise, IMHO) unless there's a higher risk or some type of symptoms. If you are able to get your report, I'd recommend you update your signature with the results. That way we don't have to keep bugging you about stuff! Your doc's point makes perfect sense. I'd say this site tends to lean towards surgery over other treatments, especially in younger guys, so if that's the route you're set to take, you'll get plenty of support and advice here. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Catheter removal times?

Posts.Content: Man, Wayne. That's a tough one. Any way you could go to the doc without your wife?! I'm on the somewhat opposite end of the spectrum--I'm procrastinating over surgery, and my wife is pestering the crap out of me about scheduling it! Are your 4 cores uni or bi-lateral (on 1 or both sides of the prostate)? Some AS programs take this into consideration. While I'm not a particularly religious man, I've generally held the belief that God helps those that help themselves. I'd say if you're a "believer" then those people in the clean white coats, as well as all of that fancy equipment, are a product of God and are here at His will to help us--and you! Kind of like the joke: There was a preacher who fell in the ocean and he couldn't swim. When a boat came by, the captain yelled, "Do you need help, sir?" The preacher calmly said "No, God will save me." A little later, another boat came by and a fisherman asked, "Hey, do you need help?" The preacher replied again, "No God will save me." Eventually the preacher drowned & went to heaven. The preacher asked God, "Why didn't you save me?" God replied, "Fool, I sent you two boats!" I'm not going to criticize another guy's wife, but her line of thinking, frankly, astounds me. I just watched my stepfather die of this disease after a 6 year battle. It wasn't pretty. I had an aunt with breast cancer that refused most medical treatment and relied on"holistic" methods. She didn't make it past 49 years old. Personally, I think you have to get some kind of treatment, whether surgery or radiation. Also personally, I don't think that I can live comfortably knowing it's still inside of me, so I'm likely going the surgery route. Good luck, man.

Posts.Content: Welcome Geezer--unfortunately you're inquiring with us. I believe the 'DCE' refers to using contrast (Dynamic contrast-enhancement) with the MRI. Did you mean 'extraprostatic extension?' If so, unfortunately, that means evidence was seen on the images that the tumor is beyond the confines of the gland into the surrounding tissue (periprostatic tissue). Please don't freak yourself out though!!! Let's get the biopsy over with and then you and your docs can decide on a plan of action. The only definitive way for a diagnoses of cancer is a biopsy. You don't have that yet, you merely have unidentified 'lesions' at this point. Additionally, can you provide your location? Maybe put it in your profile? Good luck to you, sir! Ron

Posts.Content: A bucket.....for when he 'goes' lol! Seriously though, I used Depends pads until I found the comparable 'store brand' pads worked just as well. Pharmacies (Rite Aid, Walgreen's, CVS) or grocery stores have them. I bought some adult wipes from the same section of the store. Larger than those wipes in a tube. The main thing is keeping dry and clean. I wouldn't over-worry it. It seems worse than it really is. A pad in my drawers and I never had a leak accident. Eventually I moved up to just Depends shields. I'd definitely have a pad for the ride home from the catheter removal though. You just don't know..... And enjoy cath removal day----I know HE will!!!

Posts.Content: Question regarding sildenafil--does the prescription have to be written specifically for that drug rather than Viagra? Thinking out loud I guess for when I see my primary care doc in a few weeks. But you're right on regarding the Viagra retail pricing. The first time I bought 2 tablets out of my pocket they were about $45 per. In the meantime I got a letter from BC/BS informing me that Viagra was no longer in the 'preferred' tier (never saw that happen before), thus my co-pay would increase from $10 to $20. Ok..... Well, the second time I made the purchase for 2 out of pocket they were now over $50 per! So, I suspect there was a price increase from the manufacturer causing the pills to lose their 'favorable' rating with my health insurance.

Posts.Content: I can only add that with my BC/BS Blue Preferred PPO they will only cover 6 tabs per month--no matter the reason. So, I get 6 - 100 mg tablets and quarter them up. I had a few left over prior to surgery (if I'd have known what I was about to get into, I would've started stockpiling earlier!), so I could make it an entire month, but eventually the math stopped working and I had to buy 2 extra tablets out of pocket. Well, that's about $100 for 2 freekin' pills in addition to the $20 co-pay for the 6 that are covered (was $10, but that just changed)! The pharmacist suggested considering the 5 mg daily dose of Cialis--which BC/BS appears to cover. I figure I'll mention it to my primary care doc when I see him in early March.

Posts.Content: Lance---do you mean not treated well as in the overall treatment/care you received at the hospital for your disease, or that you just didn't care for the doctors/medical staff at the hospital? And I realize lots of these 'rankings' are somewhat skewed. One of our local "What's Up (insert town name) does an annual "Top Doc" article and list. My original urologist made it, which I was happy to see as my PSA was discovered to be on the high side, yet after going through that 'good time' of a biopsy, he didn't locate the bad stuff and suggested a saturation biopsy. That's when I decided to see what Hopkins had to say, and they found it. Lucky me! BTW, your "Agent Orange" comp claim in your signature intrigues me somewhat. While it's too late for him now, my step-father, with no family history of PC, passed from it in April after a 6 year battle. He was Navy in the Vietnam era, but spent plenty of time on land there. He said "they used to drop that stuff on our heads." I don't doubt for a minute that Agent Orange was a contributing factor to his contracting the disease.

And I realize lots of these 'rankings' are somewhat skewed. One of our local "What's Up (insert town name) does an annual "Top Doc" article and list. My original urologist made it, which I was happy to see as my PSA was discovered to be on the high side, yet after going through that 'good time' of a biopsy, he didn't locate the bad stuff and suggested a saturation biopsy. That's when I decided to see what Hopkins had to say, and they found it. Lucky me! BTW, your "Agent Orange" comp claim in your signature intrigues me somewhat. While it's too late for him now, my step-father, with no family history of PC, passed from it in April after a 6 year battle. He was Navy in the Vietnam era, but spent plenty of time on land there. He said "they used to drop that stuff on our heads." I don't doubt for a minute that Agent Orange was a contributing factor to his contracting the disease.
Posts.Signature: DOB: 8/1963--Great-Grandfather/Uncle had PC 9/13 PSA 4.85, 2/14 PSA 6.7, TRUS Bx 12 core-neg, 6/14 PSA 4.8, 12/14 PSA 5.9, PCA3: 38, 1/15 PSA 5.4 (switched docs to JH), 3/15 PSA 5.8/fPSA 17.4/PHI 28.4, 3/15 3T MRI/Fusion-Guided Bx @ Johns Hopkins, 2/14 cores pos, bilateral, <5% involvement, Gleason 6, Open RP: 8/10/2015 w/ Dr. Carter @ JH Final Pathology: LN-, SV-, Margins-, EPE- Tumor Extent: Moderate, organ confined Gleason upstaged to 3+4=7 (2% pattern 4) Additional Findings: HGPIN pT2cNO (Stage IIB) PSA 11/2015 <.1, 05/2016 <.1, 09/2016 .02 & 3/2017 .02 (both using different assays), 09/2017 <.1, 03/2018 <.1
Posts.Title: I see the newest US News Hospital Rankings are out.....

Posts.Content: Welcome Geezer--unfortunately you're inquiring with us. I believe the 'DCE' refers to using contrast (Dynamic contrast-enhancement) with the MRI. Did you mean 'extraprostatic extension?' If so, unfortunately, that means evidence was seen on the images that the tumor is beyond the confines of the gland into the surrounding tissue (periprostatic tissue). Please don't freak yourself out though!!! Let's get the biopsy over with and then you and your docs can decide on a plan of action. The only definitive way for a diagnoses of cancer is a biopsy. You don't have that yet, you merely have unidentified 'lesions' at this point. Additionally, can you provide your location? Maybe put it in your profile? Good luck to you, sir! Ron

Posts.Title: Suspect MRI, awaiting Biopsy

Posts.Content: Ricker, I'd have the biopsy, but if it's available in your area (where are you located, btw?) I'd try for a 3T MRI prior to the biopsy. That way, if something suspicious is seen, the docs have something to target specifically, rather than just shoot needles in there and see if they hit something. Good luck. Ron

Posts.Content: You'll be fine, bro. Frankly, I had a pretty restful nights sleep on the 11th floor of the Zayed Tower at JH. No dogs...no bothers...and my green button to push for pain meds! Gotta say though....makes me feel a bit better that I did the 'open' route as I had no gas to purge and I even managed a small BM the following morning. Hang in there. You'll be OK.

Posts.Title: What is the best option?

Posts.Content: So, you're just a youngin' LOL! You have a low PSA, even with a G7 Gleason. And a 3+4 is thought to behave like a G6 most of the time. There are several here that would suggest you send your slides off to Johns Hopkins or Bostwick labs for a 2nd opinion, which is fine if you choose to do so. If downgraded, it may help you sleep better as you make your decisions. If I'm reading your report right, you have several cores, and many with the 3+4. Another option is to ask your uro about a 3T MP-MRI which can help assess the prostate capsule for any escape, as well as giving a peek at your lymph nodes. It all sucks, but it is what it is. As you can see by my profile, I've made it well so far.

Posts.Title: What is the best option?

Posts.Content: Interesting. While it's too late for me at this point, now 11 days post-op, I noticed that the article, when referring to Johns Hopkins, doesn't mention that JH's program requires the disease to be 'unilateral.' I thought that I was a 'shoe-in' for AS, especially since I was about to see Dr. Carter, the program's head, but although I was well within all the criteria with low % of only 2 cores.....it was on both sides, thus bilateral. I'm not so sure I'm 'wired' for AS anyways, but I didn't even get to really think about it. A check of their website indicates that the requirement is still in place.

Posts.Title: Updated new articles regarding the use of AS as a option

Posts.Content: Thanks, Michael. Deep inside I know that I made the right call, but I can't help but wonder: If I can just hold out, maybe something better will come along......Of course, if we lose that bet, well, we LOSE! I realize that I was fortunate enough to have a fine surgeon available to me. For all that I loath about living in Maryland (politically), I'm certainly fortunate to have JH only 40 minutes away. Heck, I spent the night in the tower named for the UAE Prince that came here for PC treatment! And I have to say...it was a NICE night. No yapping dogs, private room, and on the 11th floor, and not likely to catch a stray round from the Baltimore streets below! Another point about doing AS and being wired for it: We really don't know what we have until it's out and under the 'scope.

Posts.Title: Worried about reaccurance nearly 5 years post HIFU

Posts.Content: I see some stickies and all, but my head is spinning at times. I _think_ I've made the decision to go ahead and do the open removal surgery @ Hopkins, with a top doc, and then someone gives me the "are you crazy, check out Cyberknife!" routine. There are many more of you guys out here on this forum with waaaaaay more experience than I, so can some with a similar decision shine a light on this, and any discussions they've had with their medical professionals regarding this subject and the options? I'll be 52 in August. If I were several years older, I think this would be an easier decision. My worries are that 1) It's still in there, and I realize that the GS is often upgraded, and more PCa is found at pathology, 2) Radiation-related future issues (maybe even cancers? I've heard of bladder and urethral being a possibility), 3) Later treatment options if things go south, 4) Hormone Therapy seems to be a last resort if/after radiation treatment eventually fails, and IDK about that...., and 5!) To top it off, there's a guy telling me that after surgery I'll lose 1-2 inches off of my "junk!" What the hell??? Shoot me NOW!!!!! Is it still the *standard" that a younger patient has the best outcome with removal? This is all starting to suck, and mostly mentally. And I can't help but feel at times that if I could do AS for a year or two, that another solution might appear. Sorry if I rant.....The Captain (Morgan) and I are having a disagreement. LOL!!! Ron

Posts.Content: Exactly, AS. I remember the thread. Just wanted to clear things up with our other viewers--LOL! Many seem to miss the "bilateral involvement" aspect, as I did initially, too. Of course, this doesn't mean that I can't "watch and wait" myself for a while--if I can stand the pressure!!! But then it falls back to: If I have to get it out, is sooner better than later, as far as getting "functions" back? Good times!!!

Posts.Content: You'll be fine, bro. Frankly, I had a pretty restful nights sleep on the 11th floor of the Zayed Tower at JH. No dogs...no bothers...and my green button to push for pain meds! Gotta say though....makes me feel a bit better that I did the 'open' route as I had no gas to purge and I even managed a small BM the following morning. Hang in there. You'll be OK.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: My doc never mentioned a bone scan and my biopsy was also 2 cores of G6. Having said that though, I had a 3T MRI before the diagnosing biopsy, so not sure what would've been recommended if my PC was found on a standard biopsy w/o a MRI first. My PSA never was quite at your level either, though. As far as the MRI goes, it would seem to be ideal that this would be the test to go with prior to any biopsy, but it seems many/most insurance companies won't cover the expense unless the first blind biopsy is negative. Seems like their logic is reversed to me! My first uro was 'laid off' too. But because he wanted to do a saturation bippsy after my first negative biopsy, where as I wanted the MRI next.

Posts.Title: Bone scan

Posts.Content: Otago, when I met Dr. Carter after the fusion biopsy, I really thought I'd be a "shoe-in" for AS. The problem is, and I forgot about this, is that one stipulation of the AS program at JH is "unilateral disease." Unfortunately, mine is "bilateral" -- found on both sides. Lucky me! Dr. Carter mentioned a few risks of radiation, including those that I have mentioned as well as concerns about my age, but I also know the whole "of course, he's a surgeon" spiel, so that's what I expected. He also told me that on a 1-5 scale, I'm at a "one" right now (low risk), but I should seek treatment, preferably within 6 months (this was on 4/1). I didn't think to ask, but I believe the "bilateral" thing is a concern. And yes, he also told me an uncle wasn't so much a factor, but my great-grandfather is in my direct line.

Posts.Title: Treatment question, before this makes me crazy!!! Cyberknife vs. surgery?

Posts.Content: SC, my mother-in-law passed away from breast cancer related issues this past September after her aggressive treatment 3 years ago apparently caused leukemia, which came on fast and strong, and she was getting blood tests for this every 2 months. She was a non-smoker in a non-smoking household, too. A total shock to all how fast she went. I only mention this because you may want to advise your friend about it so he and his mom keep up on it as well as ask about it. I've read here on this forum that it _does_ happen. We didn't know, and she kind of kept us out of the loop on her treatment. The possibility was apparently never discussed with my in-laws. As far as the PC thing goes, I think about it in passing most days, but I don't dwell on it. Of course, with my 2nd post-op PSA coming up next week, all bets are off!

Posts.Title: William Shatner & PSA

Posts.Content: Hi Ireland. Welcome! I realize this stuff is scary. I'm glad to see your dad is reading 'The Book.' Don't fret too much that if your dad has the 'open' surgery that he'll fare worse. Dr. Walsh was a big pioneer in helping to perfect (as well as can be expected) that technique--assuming it's 'retropubic'--via the lower abdomen. A robot doesn't make a mediocre surgeon better--experience does. I had 'open' surgery nearly 11 months ago, and I'm doing well. If his scans, etc., are clean and indicate confinement, and he's able to tolerate surgery, I certainly see that as a viable option. Best of luck to you guys! My wife's dad is like, 1 generation removed from 'getting off the boat' Irish. My wife occasionally mentions that she's the only one of her siblings to have _not_ visited the homeland. Maybe we'll do. that sometime. Ron

Posts.Title: PSA in 100's

Posts.Content: SC, my mother-in-law passed away from breast cancer related issues this past September after her aggressive treatment 3 years ago apparently caused leukemia, which came on fast and strong, and she was getting blood tests for this every 2 months. She was a non-smoker in a non-smoking household, too. A total shock to all how fast she went. I only mention this because you may want to advise your friend about it so he and his mom keep up on it as well as ask about it. I've read here on this forum that it _does_ happen. We didn't know, and she kind of kept us out of the loop on her treatment. The possibility was apparently never discussed with my in-laws. As far as the PC thing goes, I think about it in passing most days, but I don't dwell on it. Of course, with my 2nd post-op PSA coming up next week, all bets are off!

Posts.Title: Trump's Reported PSA by his Dr.

Posts.Content: Hi Ireland. Welcome! I realize this stuff is scary. I'm glad to see your dad is reading 'The Book.' Don't fret too much that if your dad has the 'open' surgery that he'll fare worse. Dr. Walsh was a big pioneer in helping to perfect (as well as can be expected) that technique--assuming it's 'retropubic'--via the lower abdomen. A robot doesn't make a mediocre surgeon better--experience does. I had 'open' surgery nearly 11 months ago, and I'm doing well. If his scans, etc., are clean and indicate confinement, and he's able to tolerate surgery, I certainly see that as a viable option. Best of luck to you guys! My wife's dad is like, 1 generation removed from 'getting off the boat' Irish. My wife occasionally mentions that she's the only one of her siblings to have _not_ visited the homeland. Maybe we'll do. that sometime. Ron

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine?

Posts.Content: Hi Michael. I'd suggest scouring through the 'sticky' regarding prostate biopsy if you haven't done so already. It's not a big deal though. Was your MRI of the '3T' multiparametric variety? They appear to be the latest models out there. Will your urologist be using your MRI images with the ultrasound images from your biopsy so as to perform a 'fusion guided' biopsy? Most TRUS biopsies seem to be the standard '12 core' variety, however a fusion biopsy may require a couple more needles, but you'll be numb, so don't sweat it! You'll get a valium or something similar for the morning of, as well as an antibiotic. You'll probably be instructed to use a Fleets enema a couple hours before hand to clean your lower colon out (helps prevent infection). At the facility you'll swap out your clothes for a gown (open in the back, LOL!), lie on the table on your side with your legs drawn up towards your rear end. The doc will likely insert the lubed wand/probe for an 'ultrasound-only' look first and take some measurements of your 'parts.' Then comes the numbing needle via the probe (some docs use a numbing gel prior to the needle. I recommend this if it's an option), and then the biopsy needles, which are spring-loaded into a gun of some type. It goes pretty quickly at this point and it didn't really hurt or anything. Afterwards I had to wait in the recovery area until I could pass urine so the nurse could check it for anything unusual before I was released. Hardly any blood back there to speak of! And that's pretty much it. You'll have a little red-tinged blood for a few days and may see a small clot or two pass, but that's normal. Warning! Your seminal fluid will be pretty gross for a little while afterwards, Think TAR! Unfortunately, it's normal too. It'll eventually pass out of your system, after a while. My MRI score was a '3' also and indeterminate. And mine also showed there was no evidence my lesion had escaped the capsule, which made me feel somewhat relieved heading up to my surgery date. Has your urologist had you do a PCA3 test? I ask because of the tests I had, that's actually the one that came back with the best chance that cancer would be found on biopsy. My 'Free PSA' as well as a 'PHI' test weren't particularly favorable for cancer, the PCA3 was. P.S., can you advise your location and/or where you're getting treatment?

Posts.Title: New to this forum and looking for advice/support

Posts.Content: Hi Michael. I'd suggest scouring through the 'sticky' regarding prostate biopsy if you haven't done so already. It's not a big deal though. Was your MRI of the '3T' multiparametric variety? They appear to be the latest models out there. Will your urologist be using your MRI images with the ultrasound images from your biopsy so as to perform a 'fusion guided' biopsy? Most TRUS biopsies seem to be the standard '12 core' variety, however a fusion biopsy may require a couple more needles, but you'll be numb, so don't sweat it! You'll get a valium or something similar for the morning of, as well as an antibiotic. You'll probably be instructed to use a Fleets enema a couple hours before hand to clean your lower colon out (helps prevent infection). At the facility you'll swap out your clothes for a gown (open in the back, LOL!), lie on the table on your side with your legs drawn up towards your rear end. The doc will likely insert the lubed wand/probe for an 'ultrasound-only' look first and take some measurements of your 'parts.' Then comes the numbing needle via the probe (some docs use a numbing gel prior to the needle. I recommend this if it's an option), and then the biopsy needles, which are spring-loaded into a gun of some type. It goes pretty quickly at this point and it didn't really hurt or anything. Afterwards I had to wait in the recovery area until I could pass urine so the nurse could check it for anything unusual before I was released. Hardly any blood back there to speak of! And that's pretty much it. You'll have a little red-tinged blood for a few days and may see a small clot or two pass, but that's normal. Warning! Your seminal fluid will be pretty gross for a little while afterwards, Think TAR! Unfortunately, it's normal too. It'll eventually pass out of your system, after a while. My MRI score was a '3' also and indeterminate. And mine also showed there was no evidence my lesion had escaped the capsule, which made me feel somewhat relieved heading up to my surgery date. Has your urologist had you do a PCA3 test? I ask because of the tests I had, that's actually the one that came back with the best chance that cancer would be found on biopsy. My 'Free PSA' as well as a 'PHI' test weren't particularly favorable for cancer, the PCA3 was. P.S., can you advise your location and/or where you're getting treatment?

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: My understanding is that a 1st degree relative is more important -- a family member who shares about 50 percent of their genes with a particular individual in a family--like parents, offspring, and siblings. My father hasn't had PC (yet, anyways at 70), though his brother did in his mid 50s. So did my father's grandfather, but not HIS father, though he died of other things on the younger side, so who knows? I believe PC is considered 'sporadic' though, as many men get it with no family history. Most men probably get it and never even know, as they outlive it and die of other things.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Recurrence - PSA rising after Prostate Surgery - next steps?

Posts.Content: I meet with the Hopkins doc (H.B. Carter) next week to discuss treatment options for me. Not sure what he'll recommend for me at 51.5 years old. He told me that my situation isn't "dire" by any means. Pathology report (reviewed by Dr. Epstein) shows "Small Focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, GS 3+3=6 less than 5% involvement" in 2 of 14 cores. Dr. Carter said on a 1-5 scale,with 5 being the highest, I'm a "1"-- But I certainly don't like thinking about a "bad thing" growing inside of me! Of course, I worry about missed stuff in the biopsy, but maybe I have an edge with 2 TRUS biopsies (the last MRI-guided) within 15 months and only finding 2 cores with those 26 needles! There area lot of things, mostly political, that I get aggravated about living in Maryland. Having Johns Hopkins 30 minutes away isn't one of them though!

Posts.Title: Generic Viagra in Mexico

Posts.Content: I never cease to be amazed at the number of guys -- most of whom don't see doctors on a regular basis -- who have never heard of the PSA test. Good point Jim. I met up with a few fellow retirees of mine recently. I've made it sort of a mission to encourage guys to be sure they have their PSAs checked. I tell them my story as a case in point. All are over 50 and a few asked "how did you find out?" Mine was a routine blood test. I told them to be sure their docs are doing the same. I got the impression it hadn't occurred to them. I was guilty myself, I guess, but thankfully my regular doc was on the ball. If I hadn't forgotten about some past history, I probably would've asked for PSAs sooner.

Posts.Content: My understanding is that a 1st degree relative is more important -- a family member who shares about 50 percent of their genes with a particular individual in a family--like parents, offspring, and siblings. My father hasn't had PC (yet, anyways at 70), though his brother did in his mid 50s. So did my father's grandfather, but not HIS father, though he died of other things on the younger side, so who knows? I believe PC is considered 'sporadic' though, as many men get it with no family history. Most men probably get it and never even know, as they outlive it and die of other things.

Posts.Title: 4Kscore 12% biopsy scheduled - nervous

Posts.Content: Welcome, MJ. Any chance you can get in on a 3T mpMRI prior to a biopsy? You make some valid points, so if you end up having one, I'd recommend the fusion biopsy after a MRI. As you've probably read here, blind biopsies are just that--blind! While PC does have a familial aspect to it, my understanding is that it's also considered a 'sporadic' disease--it's more or less the luck of the draw. With an 'area of firmness' on your prostate, I'd be inclined to do the biopsy. Besides, while it's true other things may get you at your age and as you get older, the biopsy can help identify the aggressiveness of cancer---if you have it. That knowledge can help you make a decision on treatments, if any, as you move forward. While an enlarged prostate can cause some of your problems, unfortunately, so can other things. Best of luck. Ron

Posts.Title: Four month post-op update

Posts.Content: Just a quick welcome, unfortunately, before I have to run back outside into the heat and finish cutting the grass! I'm a surgery guy, so I can't really give you advice on other treatments, but you'll get some feedback soon. I believe you're the second poster within the last couple of days to list a relatively low PSA number,yet cancer was found, and of the 4+3=7 variety at that. Was there a reason for the biopsy to begin with, considering your husband's low PSA? A positive digital exam, or symptoms of some kind? Not that it matters at this point, but does his biopsy report mention 'adenocarcinoma' as his cancer type? Lately it seems there have been a few cases of the rarer, apparently more worrisome, 'intraductal' variety, which sometimes presents with a low PSA yet a higher Gleason score. As far as perineural invasion goes, my understanding is that means that cancer cells were seen tracking along the nerves that exit the prostate, but it doesn't necessarily mean the cells have escaped via those nerves. The nerve bundles surrounding the prostate are of your concern for 'nerve sparing' surgery. Which is why you want a top notch, experienced surgeon should you go that route. If the cancer is suspected of protruding into the adjacent nerve bundles, then nerve sparing would be more difficult, but since the surgeon is ready to operate, I doubt any kind of 'extension' beyond the prostate capsule is suspected. I've seen Fox Chase mentioned a few times in this forum, and I don't recall anything bad being said. As a graduate of the Johns Hopkins School of Cutlery myself, I had a good experience there, all things considered, should you wish to drive down for a second look. Speaking of Hopkins, as you've probably read here, and will probably have suggested to you, it may be worth your while to have the biopsy slides sent to Dr. Epstein's lab there for peace of mind that your pathology results are accurate. RE: ED? Depends. It takes some time as those nerves have suffered quite a shock. He'll probably be taking Viagra or another ED drug for a while. It may take up to a full year for total recovery. Practice helps. Even alone, lol! More folks will be along. Best wishes. I have to get back out there. It's not getting any cooler! Ron

Posts.Content: While not glad it was cancer, I'm glad it was the regular variety. The other variety seems to be more aggressive. My surgeon is in my profile, but it's this rookie, lol! http://urology.jhu.edu/ballentinecarter/ Note that he does the 'open' vs. 'robotic' procedure, but I'm also a believer that a robot doesn't make a mediocre surgeon better. Experience does. His bio page states over 3500 RP surgeries performed, but it said that over 2 years ago when I was diagnosed. I imagine it's at least 4000 now. Nice enough fella, and I had good results, all in all. I actually enjoyed my private room on the 11th floor for the night. No barking dogs or crazy cats, and high enough from the street that I wasn't likely to catch a stray round from below! I wouldn't have minded a second night of peace and quiet, but after seeing what the insurance was billed, THAT wasn't going to happen! You know, in a way, be glad that nodule was found. With his low PSA readings, it may have very well gotten farther along before a biopsy was ordered. Yeah, I finished. Though I was gonna pass out there at the end! Hot, humid, Maryland summers! Ron P.S. Feel free to private message me should you have any more questions about my doc or JH. There are many things about living in this state that annoy me, but after losing a little faith after my first uro missed my PC during a biopsy, and my PSA still too high, I ran, not walked the 40 minutes to JH!

Posts.Title: Early Detection/Ben Stiller

Posts.Content: Welcome, MJ. Any chance you can get in on a 3T mpMRI prior to a biopsy? You make some valid points, so if you end up having one, I'd recommend the fusion biopsy after a MRI. As you've probably read here, blind biopsies are just that--blind! While PC does have a familial aspect to it, my understanding is that it's also considered a 'sporadic' disease--it's more or less the luck of the draw. With an 'area of firmness' on your prostate, I'd be inclined to do the biopsy. Besides, while it's true other things may get you at your age and as you get older, the biopsy can help identify the aggressiveness of cancer---if you have it. That knowledge can help you make a decision on treatments, if any, as you move forward. While an enlarged prostate can cause some of your problems, unfortunately, so can other things. Best of luck. Ron

DoctorRecommended.Sample: The nurse suggested that I try to hold my stream as I'm urinating to get into practice. I tried it and I was able to stop the flow, albeit not nearly as quickly as before the surgery, but it's a (hopeful) start....I encourage anyone scheduling surgery at JH to go, and my understanding is that they are matching the upcoming surgeries with patients in order to invite patients to attend. Good slide show and a good question/answer session afterwards with a Urology Nurse Practitioner....
